Olga is requesting a loan of 9,750 Grivnyas to increase the assortment of merchandise she offers for sale to tourists vacationing in Western Ukraine. Olga usually makes a good profit in the winter,  when many tourists come to the Carpathians to ski. She is seeking to expand her small venture and generate additional income. Olga hopes to use additional profits generated by the loan to remodel her home.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of merchandise for sale.

loans.name: God Blessing Group

texts.en:
God Blessing is a group of five borrowers, led by Oretha S., that live and work near Red Light in Paynesville, Liberia.  Red Light is the country's largest market, and is about 10 kilometers from the capital Monrovia.  It is a bustling area full of shops, stalls, and vendor tables.

Oretha is 35 years old and is engaged to be married -- "I pray to God it will be soon," Oretha says of her wedding.  She has four children, two girls and two boys, and also takes care of her mother.  All of her children are in school now; the oldest, a boy, is 20 and in the 11th grade, and the youngest, a 12-year-old girl, is in the 5th grade.

Many Liberians had their schooling interrupted by years of civil war and conflict, but now that peace has come they are returning to school to finish their studies.  Oretha herself has only been able to complete the 6th grade, and she has no plans to return to school at this time.

Oretha started her business selling lapa, lace, and linen in 2002.  Lapa is patterned, printed African fabric; Oretha is wearing a dress made of lapa in the photo that accompanies this profile.  She says most of the lapa she buys and resells is imported from Togo. She sells from a table at the Red Light market.  Most of her customers are women, but men also buy the lapa she sells.  She says of her business:  "I take care of it and manage it well."  Oretha plans to use her 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 37,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more lapa and lace.  

Oretha hopes to be able to grow her business enough so that she can open a proper storefront at the Red Light market.  She also wants to be able to help her children finish their education, "so they can help me in my old age."


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Oretha is the one holding the sign.  Kumbah N. is inset at lower right.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy lapa (printed African cloth), linen, and lace.

loans.name: Let God Be God Group

texts.en: Let God Be God is a group of five borrowers, led by Garma G., who live and work near the Red Light market in Paynesville, Liberia. Red Light is the country's largest market, and is about ten kilometers from the capital, Monrovia. It is a bustling area full of shops, stalls, and vendors’ tables. Garma is 36 years old and is unmarried but has a partner. "My first man died," she says, "But I have a second man." Garma has three children: a three-year-old girl and two boys aged 12 and 16; her boys both attend school. Garma herself never went to school, but instead worked with her mother who operated a dry foodstuffs business similar to Garma's. Garma's parents have both passed away. Garma sells beans, peppers, mustard seed, and other dry foodstuffs from a table at the Red Light market. She says she's been at her current location for three years. This is her first loan from Kiva partner LEAP, and she plans to use her 5,000 Liberian dollar portion of the 24,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more inventory for her business. Garma hopes that her business will be even more successful. She says she looks forward to the day when her children can help her with the business, and hopes that they will be able to take care of her when she gets old. In the photo, Garma is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy dry foodstuffs such as beans, peppers, and mustard seed

loans.name: We Will Rejoice Group

texts.en:
We Will Rejoice is a group of five borrowers, led by Saybah D., that live and work near the Red Light market in Paynesville, Liberia.  Red Light is the country's largest market, and is about 10 kilometers from the capital Monrovia.  It is a bustling area full of shops, stalls, and vendor tables.

Saybah is 38 years old and is married with two children, Esther, a five-year-old daughter who is in kindergarten, and K., a two-year-old son (who is visible in the photo that accompanies this profile, peeK. over Saybah's shoulder).

Saybah's sells foodstuffs such as beans and cooK. oil from a table at the Red Light market.  Saybah has had the business for five years, and says her biggest challenge has been fluctuating wholesale prices of the foodstuffs she buys for resale.  This is Saybah's first loan from Kiva partner LEAP, and she plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more inventory for her business.

Saybah hopes to build a proper storefront for her business one day, and says "God will make a way for me."  She has big dreams for her children: Esther is to become a journalist, and K. a doctor.  Saybah also has plans for herself -- she says if she gets the opportunity, she'll go to university to study nursing.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Saybah is the one holding the sign.  Sawon B. is inset at lower right. 

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs for resale, such as beans and cooking oil.

loans.name: Aun's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Aun C. is a pig breeder. She is 51 years old and the mother of three children who are employed in a garment factory. Her husband, Mr. Chhuok Van, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Now he faces an obstacle because he does not have enough money to grow rice in the field during the dry season. Thus, Mrs. Aun C. decided to ask for a loan to buy farming supplies to support the rice farming. She is the  leader of a four member group who all live in Srae Vong village in Takeo province.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies

loans.name: Mrs. Uok Sok  Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan group consists of ten members who receive individual loans but who are bound by a group guarantee. Mrs. Uok S. is the village bank president who lives in Thma Sa village in Takeo province. 

She is a salt middle-woman. Her husband, Mr. C. Nub, is a motorbike repairer. He needs some equipment to support this work and to make it better. Thus, Mrs. Uok S. is requesting a loan to buy a machine to support the motorbike store. She is 37 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others attend the local school. Mr. Bros S. and Mr.Thy T. did not come to take loan but their wife were, so they are presented in the picture instead.

loans.use: Equipment for motorcycle repair shop

loans.name: Mrs. Ngon Toum Group

texts.en:
Twenty people who are all living in Thnuoh village in the TaK. province make up this village bank loan. Mrs. NgO. T. is the village-bank president who has been selected by the members, who all will use the loan for different purposes. 

She is a farmer who owns a plot of land for cultivating rice. Her husband, Mr. S. Chea, is fisherman. Now he needs more fishnets to support his fishing. Thus, Mrs. NgO. T. decided to ask for a loan to buy more bamboo for her husband to make fishnets. 

She is 40 years old and the mother of two children, both of whom are enrolled in the local school. All the members are shown in the picture, but one of tH. is blocked.

loans.use: To buy more bamboo for her husband to make fishnets

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en:
Cecelia B. is 44 years old and has five children. She said that her income from her refrigeration business has helped her a lot in managing their finances. 

She wishes to apply for a loan at Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner. She will use the loan to pay for needs in her shop and pay the laborers as well. She hopes she could have a good return on investment. 

What she likes about the CEVI program is that it has helped not just her, but other women in the community as well.

loans.use: To pay laborers in her refrigeration shop

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie M. owns a fishing boat. Her husband has been a fisherman since 2000. She has one child, who is 3 years old. She said that the loans she has taken from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., have helped her buy appliances at home. Loans have also helped her sustain her seaweed farm. 

Now she would like to reapply for a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos. She will use the loan to obtain more fish to resell. The loan will also help in buying seaweed seedlings for her seaweed business.

loans.use: Obtain more fish to resell

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Fifty-three-year-old Lolita T. is a fish buyer. She has nine children; the eldest is thirty-seven years old. Lolita says that she has a great market for selling fish. She dreams of being able to meet all of the needs in her family every day, of having good health, and of repaying her loans. She is reapplying for a loan of PHP 8,000 to enable her to add capital to her business; she hopes to receive a loan to buy more fish to resell in the market.

loans.use: To buy more fish to resell in the market

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en: Natividad C., 47 years old, is a busy vendor of cucumber and seaweed. She has four children. The eldest, 28 years old, helps her run the business. She says that her business is doing well now but sometimes, especially if there is bad weather, she cannot be certain she will have good profit from her business. She has applied for a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to buy fish to resell and seaweed seedlings.

loans.use: To obtain more fish to resell and seaweeds seedlings

loans.name: Felomina

texts.en: Felomina C., 50 years old, makes and sells Polvoron (a sweet delicacy) and fish in Talibon, Bohol. She works everyday to earn her daily income. She has two adult children and she endures working so hard to be able to provide all the needs of her family. She said that her business has helped a lot to provide for their daily needs. That is why she is doing the best way she can to prosper and improve the turnaround in her business. She wants to re-apply for a loan of PHP 12,000. The loan will go for buying more fish to resell.

loans.use: To obtain more fish to sell

loans.name: Bienvinida

texts.en: Bienvinida P., 55 years old, has a pumpboat service.She uses it to transport passengers from the island to the mainland of Talibon, Bohol. She earns income with this business and this is what sustains her family. She wants to re-apply for a loan of PHP 12,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. to use for the maintenance and repair of her boat.

loans.use: Boat repair

loans.name: Edelyn

texts.en: Edelyn L., 31 years old, is a fish vendor. She has a boat, which her husband uses to catch fish. She has three children. Her eldest child is 10 years old. She also sells crabs. She wants to improve her family's economic situation. She wants to re-apply for a loan of PHP 10,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy fishing materials and fish to resell.

loans.use: Obtain fish to resell and buy fishing nets

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en: Cecilia S. dreamed of having a house. She is 28 years old and raises pigs. She has three children. Her oldest is six. She enjoys cleaning the barn all day and feeding her pigs. She said that, for now, she is doing great in her business. She wants to re-apply for a loan to sustain her livelihood. She hopes to receive a loan of PHP 7,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy pig feed and additional piglets.

loans.use: To buy piglets and feed

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en: Letecia C., 44 years old, is a fish vendor. She owns a boat, which her husband uses to catch fish. She is childless. Aside from fish, she wants to have another line of business. She wants to augment her family's economic situation. She wants to re-apply for a loan of PHP 12,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy fishing materials and fish to resell.

loans.use: To obtain more fish to resell

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Alma G., 48 years old, is from Veruela, Agusan Del Sur. She has a farm, which she hopes will provide her family with their daily needs. She wishes to increase her livelihood to be able to improve her family's economic situation. She wants to apply for a loan of PHP 6,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Amparo

texts.en: Amparo A. has been married for 24 years. She is a rice grower from Veruela, Agusan Del Sur. The income, which she gets from growing rice, has helped her family a lot to buy food and other basic needs. Now, she has a little problem financing her rice farm. That is why she needed to apply for a loan of PHP 6,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc to buy farm supplies and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Savang

texts.en:
Mrs. Savang R. (pictured here), 32, and her husband, Mr. Saroeung Soem, 37, were married in 1993 and have two children: one son and one daughter. Both of them are in school. They live with their parents on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Savang has been a silk weaver for 12 years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been a farmer for over two years. She is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase fertilizer, pesticides and seeds to maintain her husband’s farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides and seeds

loans.name: Erlina

texts.en:
Erlina I., 49, owns a small rice farm. This farm helps her buy the things her family asks for, like food, clothes and other basic necessities. She said that if she does not work hard on her farm, she won’t get anything for her family. 

Now she is having difficulty maintaining her 1-hectare farm because of financial constraints in the family. She would like to apply for a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Harry

texts.en: Harry A., 44 years old, seeks a good life for his family. He has five children. His eldest is no longer studying because they don’t have enough money to pay for education. Farming is what sustains the family. That is why he has been working very hard to improve their harvest. He would like to apply for a loan of PHP 6,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizer.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Nicolasa

texts.en: When you are 51, you will always think of your family, including your grandchildren. Nicolasa M., despite her age, is still growing rice in their village because she wants to help her children and grandchildren. She has a rice farm and a sari-sari store. Her businesses help her buy food and other basic needs. Now, she needs a small amount to support her farm. She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 6,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizer.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Imelda's Group

texts.en: Imelda S. is from the village of Sagana, Santiago. She is 49 years old. Imelda is the group leader of a 12-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Imelda S.'s group. Imelda is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Imelda runs a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Imelda has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2005, Imelda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Imelda is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sonida

texts.en: Mrs. Sonida S. (in the photo) and her husband are silk weavers. They have been married since 2009 and live on an island on the Mekong River about 15 km. from Phnom Penh City. The couple sells the finished products to a middleman who, in turn, sells it in Phnom Penh market. Sonida is applying for a loan of $300 to purchase cotton thread for the business she and her husband have.

loans.use: To purchase cotton thread for her weaving business.

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en: Rosana O. is a 30-year-old rice farmer who has three children. Because her eldest child is only 4 years old, she has been quite worried about how to manage their income when her children start going to school. She would like to grow her rice farm business. She has been busy preparing it for the next planting. However, she said, she still needs additional money to complete the process. She is now applying for a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Honorato

texts.en: Honorato P., 51 years old, owns a small rice field. He has seven children; the eldest is 26 years old. The farm that he has tilled for so many years has been very helpful to him and his family, allowing him to buy basic necessities for the home. He would like to increase his harvest. A loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. will really help him achieve his goals. If he gets a loan, he will buy fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Cherry's Group

texts.en:
Cherry A. is from the village of Brgy. Pieza, Villaverde, Nueva Vizcaya. She is thirty-three years old. Cherry is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Cherry is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Cherry owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for her business comes primarily from raising and fattening pigs for sale. Cherry has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for this work.

In 2009, Cherry joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to make her more capable of engaging in business activities. Cherry has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. The previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise for future sale. Cherry is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be her second loan from ASKI; she will use this loan to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the central and northeastern areas of the Philippines. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Sarem

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarem Y., 67, has one son who is an English teacher. She lives in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sarem has been selling groceries for 10 years. Her husband assists her in the business. Sarem hopes to expand her business to better respond to her customers' needs. She is asking for her first loan of $500 to purchase additional grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items for resale

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en: Just like other farmers, 44-year-old Remedios I. wants to grow a bountiful harvest. Currently, she tills a hectare of rice field, but she needs additional money to buy all of the farming necessities. She would like to apply for a loan of 6,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.use: Fertilizers and farm supplies

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en: Rosalyn E. manages a small rice field. She has three children; her eldest is nine years old. Her husband is also a farmer, and they work together to improve their harvest in order to support their children. The family is now preparing the farm for another planting, and they need additional money to buy all of the farming materials. She would like to apply for a loan of 6,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm Supplies and fertilizer

loans.name: Rolly

texts.en: Rolly G. is a farmer. As the head of his family, he finds ways to provide his family with an adequate supply of food, clothing, and other basic needs. He has been tilling his farm for many years now, and it always keeps him busy. He would like to apply for a loan of 6,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm Supplies and fertilizer

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Mrs. Leng S. (pictured here), 38, and her husband, Mr. Ang Un, 43, were married in 1987 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. Two of them work in a garment factory, one is a security guard and the other two attend school. The family lives in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Leng has been a garment-factory worker for six years, while her husband has been a construction worker for 10 years. Because their children commute to school far away, they take a motor remoque or motor taxi very often. A remoque is a motorcycle with a trailer on the back. Taking a remoque or motor taxi to school is expensive for the family. Therefore, Leng is asking for her first loan of $600 to buy a motorbike for her children to drive to school.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to drive to school

loans.name: Lucita

texts.en: Lucita P., 48, is a tenant of a two-hectare rice field. She has six children. She helps her husband manage their farm so that they will have an abundant harvest to feed their family. She dreams of having a farm someday, that is why she is doing her best to be able to prosper and improve their harvest. She would like to apply for a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Mergelyn

texts.en: “We have a one-hectare farm, which we till for so many years now. It is our only source of livelihood. That is why we keep our best to sustain it so that we could provide our family with all their needs,” says Mergelyn C., a twenty-five-year-old farmer from Veruela, Agusan Del Sur. Now, she is preparing the farm, but she still needs an additional amount of money to buy all of the supplies she needs for farming. She hopes to receive a loan of PHP 6,000 through Community Economic Ventures, Inc., She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and farm supplies

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine V., 24, is a rice farmer. Her husband works in a bakery and was assigned to delivery. The income she makes from her farm is really helpful in ensuring the supply of food for their family. She really would like to grow her harvest but needs a small amount of money to buy all the farming necessities like fertilizers and farm supplies. She would like to apply for a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner. The loan will mean growing her harvest.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en: Lorna O., 56 years old, is a rice grower. She has a small rice field which she has maintained for many years now to ensure a good supply of food for her family. Currently she is happy with the status of her business. It’s growing and improving every year. Now she needs a small amount of money to buy farm supplies and fertilizers. She would like a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She chose CEVI because it provides – not just loans – but insurance coverage as well to all its clients.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en: Evangeline P. is a fifty-four-year-old widow. She is managing her farm alone and is hoping for an abundant harvest. She says she learned learned to farm when she was just a child. Her parents taught her everything. She wants to make her farm productive in honor of her late husband. She is applying for a loan of PHP 6,000 at Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and fertilizers

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy L., who is forty years old, and her husband, Mr. Neang Nou, who is forty-two years old (the two are pictured together), live about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1993 and have two children. Their one son is attending school and they have a young daughter.  

In the past, Chanthy used to be a garment factory worker. Now, she has just started a new tailoring business at her house. Her husband is an aide-de-camp. She is asking for a loan of $300 to add to her own money to purchase a motorbike for her son to drive to school.

loans.use: To add to her own money to purchase a motorbike for her son to drive to school.

loans.name: Sally

texts.en: Sally D., a rice grower from Veruela, Agusan del Sur, wishes to obtain a loan to improve her harvest by buying better farm supplies. She has seven children. Her eldest child is 24 years old. She is quite happy with the income she earns from growing rice on her farm. She hopes to receive a loan of 6,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures Inc. because in addition to providing loans, they also enroll all of their clients into an insurance program.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Ma. Leah

texts.en:
Ma. Leah D. is a 33-year-old, married woman who lives in Cabay, Brgy Guihalaran, Silay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living from a pig-fattening business. She buys piglets when they are small, and then raises them, feeds them, and fattens them for sale when they reach an appropriate size. This is also called piggery, which is also the name for the pen where the pigs are kept. In order to keep a business like Ma. Leah's running, she needs to be constantly buying new piglets and more feed so that the pigs can bring in a high price when she sells them. Project Dungganon helps by providing the capital to make this happen.

Ma. Leah’s husband, Joseph, has another job to support their family. They have three children ranging from an infant to 15 years old. Two of the children attend school, but they also help their parents with the business as part of their daily chores.

Ma. Leah joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 with the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of the loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase her family income, earning an additional Php 8,000 from her business activities.

Ma. Leah is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 14,000 was used to fund and maintain her pig-fattening business by helping her purchase feed and other supplies. It had a positive impact on both her business and the family’s living conditions. Now, she is borrowing her 8th loan, in the amount of Php 15,000, which she intends to use for the same purposes. Ma. Leah D. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:


In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en: Lilia N. is 64 years old and is a rice farmer. She said that she has benefited a lot from growing rice. Her husband is also a farmer. Both of them work hard to earn an income for their family. She hopes to improve her harvest, but she needs additional capital to buy all of the farming necessities. She would like to apply for a loan of 6,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will be used to buy fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm Supplies and fertilizer

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena S., 36, is a rice farmer. She has three children, the eldest of whom is 10 years old. She tills a small rice field in Veruela, Agusan del Sur. She has been married for 11 years. She wanted to grow her business more to be able to provide her children an adequate supply of food, clothing and other basic needs. 

She said that aside from growing rice, she also raises hogs. She wanted to apply for a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en: Nelly E., 44 years old, tills a small rice farm that she owns. She has eight children. She dreams of having a good harvest to earn a better income for her family. She needs additional money to buy all the farming necessities like fertilizers and seeds. She would like a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. The loan will help a lot to sustain her livelihood and realize her plans for her family.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Marlina's Group

texts.en: Marlina L. is from the village of Victoria, Alicia, Isabela. She is 51 years old. Marlina is the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Marlina is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Marlina makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling frozen products, fish and tamarind fruits. Marlina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Marlina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marlina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Marlina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en: Leonora A. is a 52-year-old married woman who lives in Prk Cubay, Brgy Guinhalaran, Silay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three trisikads. For those of you that do not know what a trisikad is, allow me to shed some light for you. A trisikad is a typical means of transportation in the Philippines. It is a BMX bike with a small sidecar attached. Inside is a padded seat big enough to fit two (though as many as five people can fit on a trisikad at one time). This is different from a tricycle which is a motorbike with a sidecar attached. Leonora owns three trisikads, all of which are used to generate income for her family. Leonora’s husband, Raul, also helps run the business. They have two children ages 21 and 27 years old. The two children work and help the family financially. Leonora wants to buy another trisikad and expand her business. This is a great opportunity for you to help a Kiva borrower expand her business. Leonora joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in March of 2002 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income, earning an extra 4,800 Philippine pesos (PHP) from her business activities. Leonora is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of 14,000 PHP was used to fund the operations of her trisikad business and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is requesting her 17th loan, for 10,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy a trisikad. Leonora is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy a trisikad

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en: When she started her business in 2005, Merlinda F.'s goal was making her business grow to support her family. She is 45 years old and tills a small rice field, which is 1 hectare in size. She wants to have an abundant harvest but lacks capital for buying all the farm supplies she needs. She would like to request a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner. The loan will really help her go on in her farming business and have a sustainable income for the family.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Renith

texts.en:
As a mother of two children, Renith F. dreams of having a sustainable livelihood for her family. Currently Renith, who is only 28, has a farm. She grows and sells rice to provide her children all their needs. The income she makes from growing rice helps pay for the school tuition and books. It also helps pay for the daily costs in their home. 

She desires to add business capitalization. She wants to apply for a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner. The loan will go far in buying farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline B., 38, is a tenant of a small parcel of rice farm in Veruela, Agusan Del Sur. She is also the mother of a 3-year-old child. Evangeline desires for her business to be prosperous to be able to save money for the future of her family. 

Currently, they are planting rice seedlings. She would like to grow her harvest so that she will be able to get more rice grain. Deep inside, she desires to have her own farm. She would like to ask for a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Emiliano

texts.en:
Emiliano S., 53, is never tired of tilling his farm. He said that his purpose and desire is to help his family have an adequate supply of food every day. He will continue to do his best to sustain his livelihood so that he can still support his children even though they are already married.  

He would like to ask for a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Ya

texts.en:
Mr. Ya Y., 52, and his wife, Mrs. Man Son (pictured together), 51, live in a village along national road number one approximately 20km from Phnom Penh City. They have only one son who attends school. Besides his son, he also has his elderly mother living with him.  

Ya has been driving a motor taxi in Phnom Penh for four years. Mrs. Man Son has been running a grocery store in her village for 24 years. Ya is asking for his first loan of $800 to build a new shop and buy additional grocery items for his wife’s inventory.

loans.use: To build a new shop and buy groceries to sell

loans.name: Annabel

texts.en:
Annabel A. is from the village of Sicayab. She is 51 years old, married and the mother of 4 adult-aged children. Annabel owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Annabel has been involved in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Annabel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Annabel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Annabel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to increase working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Annabel from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and to increase working capital

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita I. is a 33-year-old married woman living in the green farm country of the Rizal province town of Morong. She has two minor children. One child is a college student and the other is a nursery student. Over the years, she has provided for her family by raising and slaughtering hogs and by selling Avon products in her village.

This loan of 28,000 Philippine pesos is for hog fattening, a common business for people in her area suffering from poverty. She will buy ten small piglets, five sacks of feed, and supplements and vitamins for the piglets. She will raise them for approximately four to six months until they are ready for sale.

Her biggest dream is to have a successful pig farm someday. She believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed while helping her family rise out of poverty. The financial opportunity of hog fattening is one of the best ways to help provide for her family and she very much wants to lift her family out of poverty.

loans.use: To purchase piglets, feed, supplements and vitamins

loans.name: Mr. Nhim Mao Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of 25 people and they all live in Thnuoh village in TaK. province. Mr. Nhim M. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land where he cultivates rice to earn a living. He is also a cow middleman. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it by purchasing a cow for breeding and to resell to earn more profit. Mr. Nhim M. is 29 years old and a  widower with two children who are both enrolled in the local school. Mr. Bros U. and Mr. Rom K. do not come to take the loan but their wifves do, so they are presented in the picture instead.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida P. is a widowed woman who supports her family by running a pig fattening business. She lives in Sitio Maninihon, Brgy Guinhalaran, Silay City, Negros Occidental with her only child.  He is 30 years old and already has a family of his own.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1988 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her pig fattening business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,000.

Zenaida is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can expand her business, buying more piglets and more feed. This will be her 26th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Zenaida aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy piglets and feed

loans.name: Sreymao

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreymao M. (pictured here), 39, and her husband, Mr. Norng Chea, 33, were married in 2000 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Two of them are in school and the other two are still young. They live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Sreymao has been a silk weaver for 15 years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in the Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been a fisherman for 20 years. Sreymao is asking for her first loan of $200 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Chanleab's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanleab S. is the group leader of a four-member group loan. All the members live in Damrei Chhlang village in the Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land for cultivating both rice and vegetables. 

In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to grow rice in the dry season. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Saem Sae, is a fisherman. This couple has four children, three of whom are attending the local school while the remaining one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to grow rice in the dry season

loans.name: Sambat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambat V. (in the photo), 54, and her husband, Mr. Set Sam, 62, live on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1979 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. Two of their children are married and live in separate homes, two others assist their mother in the weaving business and the youngest daughter is in school.

Sambat has been a silk weaver since 1980, having learned the skill from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in the Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a primary-school teacher. 

Sambat has requested a Kiva loan via Maxima one other time already. She is now requesting another loan in the amount of $100 to purchase more silk materials for continuing her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
Aileen A. is a 36-year-old mother of two. She hails from the beautiful city of Morong, Rizal Province in the Philippines. Her eldest daughter, Trixie, is a 16-year-old high school student. Her youngest, Jayvee, is a 15-year-old high school student. Aileen is married to 38-year-old Gilbert, her partner in business and a carpenter.

Aileen joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and a Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2006. Since then, she has had to acquire capital for her business. She used her first to fourth loans for the direct selling of Avon and Natasha products. It has been great for her family. The business is running smoothly and bringing in enough proceeds. Now on her fifth loan, Aileen is applying for 25,000 pesos as additional capital for her business.

She hopes that in the near future, she can build a more durable concrete house. And she also dreams of sending her children to school up to college so they can find good jobs. She is hoping to have more stock for selling for her business.

loans.use: Additional capital for direct selling of Avon and Natasha products

loans.name: Chenda

texts.en:
Mr. Chenda Y. (shown in the photo), age 37, and his wife, Mrs. Sinat Un, age 35, married in 2000 and just have one son who is attending school. The family is living in a small village off of National Road number Two about 20 kilometers south of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Chenda and his wife have been selling fish for a year. They buy fish from Prek Toch market and transport it to sell in Phnom Penh market. Chenda is requesting his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for his nephew to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his nephew to drive to work.

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun N., 50, has been selling dried fish in the market for years. She is married with a teenage child who attends school. Her husband operates a trailer-motor taxi. Bun N. always buys fresh fish in bulk and turns them into dried fish for sale, enabling her to generate $4 per day to help cover her family’s daily expenses. Bun N. has an old house which is frequently in disrepair, and her daily living conditions have been affected. To solve the problem, Bun N. is looking for a $1200 loan to be used to decorate and repair her old house.

loans.use: To decorate and repair her old house

loans.name: Tagoykul

texts.ru: Маматалиев Тагойкул проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 46 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Маматалиев Тагойкул имеет собственный земельный участок. Растениеводством занимается более 20 лет. Целью кредита является посев овощей.
texts.en:
Tagoykul M. lives close to Yavan, Tajikistan. He is forty-six and married with five children. Tagoykul M. has a piece of land. He has been growing plants for over twenty years. He is asking for loan to grow vegetables.

Translated from Russian by Susan Savkov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grow Vegetables

loans.name: Yen

texts.en:
Mrs. Yen C. (pictured here), 56, and her husband, Mr. Mao Meach, 66, were married in 1973 and have nine children. Four of them are married and live outside the family home, two attend primary school and the other children assist their parents in  their farming business. They live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Yen and her husband are farmers. They grow many kinds of vegetables such as ginger, taro, corn and tomato. The couple doesn’t have enough capital to maintain their farm. So, Yen is asking for her first loan of $800 to purchase fertilizer, pesticides, and seeds, and to pay for the plowing fee.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and pay for plowing

loans.name: Jenny-Ann

texts.en:
Jenny-ann E. is from the village of Antipolo. She is 28 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children.

Jenny-ann owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling wild-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Jenny-ann joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to repair her fishing boat.

Jenny-ann is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials for repairing her fishing nets. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC, and her second from Kiva. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.  (The fishing activity of Jenny-ann is fish fence commonly known as "bunsod".  It is made of bamboo posts attached with nets.  The cage appears in the photo is the end point of the wide fence where the fish, crabs,and squids can be trapped.) 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials to repair her fishing nets

loans.name: Kimchheng

texts.en: Mrs. Kimchheng S. is 52 years old and she lives in Angk village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Miech Van, are farmers who own a small piece of land where they cultivate rice. In the rice field, this family faces some problem because they don't have enough rice seed and the soil is infertile. Thus, Mrs. Kimchheng S. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizer to increase the rice yield. She is a mother of six children. Two of the children are laborers, two are employed in a garment factory and two attend a local public school. Her husband is presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en: Vorn B., 35, is a married man and a father of two young children. He helps feed his children by working as a construction worker. His wife, Phally, is 27 years old, and she sells a few fresh fish around the community. Vorn B. desires to earn extra income by investing in the animal trade, buying and selling animal.  But this is not possible because he doesn’t have money to start the business process. Therefore, he is pursuing a loan of $700 from Kiva’s partner, HKL. He will buy animals such as oxen and horses from rural farmers. He will fatten them for a while before selling them out to people who need them to allow their labor in transportation base. This will provide him with additional money.

loans.use: To buy a cow and a horse.

loans.name: Chanry

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanry T. is a villager in Angk village in the Kandal province. She is 24 years old. She is a farmer who owns 1 hectare of land for cultivating rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Pouv Ngoun, is a fisherman who can earn a little income to support his family. This family does not have enough money to support their rice field. Moreover, their rice field has infertile soil and it is far from an irrigation system. Thus, Mrs. Chanry T. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and fuel to pump water to support the field. 

She is the mother of a child who is too young to go to school or work. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and fuel to pump water to support the field

loans.name: Hou

texts.en:
Mrs. Hou L., 53, and her husband, Mr. Ny Choem, 54, were married in 1972. They have six sons and four daughters. Four of their children are married and live outside the family home, three are garment-factory workers and the other children attend school. Hou was not in the photo, but her husband was available instead. 

Hou used to be a silk weaver, but she quit the business and runs a new business selling vegetables in the local market. Her husband is a fisherman and wooden-house repairer. They can not manage on his income to support the family. Because their motorbike is old, it costs her a lot of money to make repairs. Thus Hou is applying for a loan of $500 to add to her own money to purchase a new motorcycle to replace the old one.

loans.use: To add to her own money to purchase a new motorbike to replace the old one

loans.name: Avelcan

texts.en:
Avelcan M. is from the village of Sicayab. She is 51 years old. Avelcan is married and has five children.  Three of her children are adults and two are school-aged.  To make a living, Avelcan owns & operates a food stall selling ground pork and beef products called "longganisa" in the local community. Avelcan has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Avelcan joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Avelcan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Avelcan is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used for the same purpose. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Avelcan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living condition of the family and for her children's education. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Mansur

texts.ru: Намозов Мансур проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 33 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Намозов Мансур имеет высшее Медицинское образование по специальности "Врач". Растениеводством занимается 4 года. Он сажает и переработав продает. Целью кредита является закуп семян.
texts.en:
Mansur N. lives close to Yavan, Tajikistan. He is thirty-three and married with five children. Mansur graduated from medical school as a doctor. He has been growing plants for four years. He grows the plants and after processing, sells them. He is asking for a loan to purchase seeds.

Translated from Russian by Susan Savkov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seeds

loans.name: Progressive Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
S. Joseph is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. He is a hardworking man and a businessman with multiple businesses including a boda boda (motorbike taxi) business. He also buys and sells agricultural produce, he is a builder and has a retail shop at his home which is mostly managed by his wife with the help of his children.

Joseph has four children and he hopes to see all of them attain the best education even through to university so that they can have a better life than the one they are living today. Joseph needs this first loan to be able to expand his business by restocking his retail shop with more goods as well as to buy more agricultural produce and greens for resale.

loans.use: To restock his retail shop and to buy more agricultural produce for resale

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Mrs. Kong N., 47, and her husband, Mr. Nhaun Kheav, 48, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, They were married in 1983 and have five children: four sons and one daughter. The oldest son works in a garment factory and the others attend school.

Kong has been selling vegetables and meat for more than six years; she buys it from Phnom Penh for resale in the village. Her husband has been a construction worker for more than ten years. Besides the business, he is also a motorbike taxi driver. Kong is requesting a loan of $1,200 to repair the motorbike. She will also use part of her loan to buy more vegetables and meat for resale.

loans.use: To repair a motorbike and to buy vegetables and meat for resale

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en:
Romeo A. is from the village of Sta. Isabel. He is 63 years old. Romeo is single. To make a living, Romeo provides vulcanizing and repair services to local community and members. Romeo has been engaged in his business for over 40 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Romeo joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Romeo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. Romeo is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the 20th loan taken out by Romeo from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business and to save for future use. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Ya

texts.en: Mrs. Ya F., 55 years old, is a cake seller in the Bei Village in the Chrung Comres I Sangkat in Phnom Penh City. She takes care of 11 children and earns about $3 a day. Her husband, Mr. Rim Ly, is a 62-year-old motorcycle taxi driver who earns about $2 a day. Ya F. has three children who help support the family by working in a garment factory. Ya F. wants to encourage her unemployed children to have a suitable job but they don’t have money to invest in a job. So Ya F. is requesting a loan for her children to use as capital to begin selling fruit and fish paste in the market.

loans.use: To finance a business selling fruit and fish paste

loans.name: Dalim

texts.en:
Mrs. Dalim C., 38, and her husband, Mr. Tiny Pin, 45, live in a small village in the suburbs of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 2000 and have two children: one son and one daughter. One goes to school and the other one stays at home.  

Mrs. Dalim C. is a garment factory worker, while her husband is a motorbike taxi driver. He drives in Phnom Penh and is able to earn 25,000 riel (about $6.25) per day. The couple is in the process of building a new house, but it isn't finished yet. So, Dalim is asking for her first loan of $500 in order to finish the house.

loans.use: To finish building a new house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Chroeng

texts.en:
Mr. Chroeng Y., 50, (pictured here) and his wife Mrs. Eang Um, 48, live along National Road Number One, about 35 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have six children: five sons and one daughter, two of whom are garment factory workers.

Chroeng and his wife have been producing rice wine and raising pigs for 15 years. He is applying for his first loan of $800 in order to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his business of producing rice wine and raising pigs

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma P. is from the village of  Mambajao, Camiguin province. She is 45 years old, is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies like cassava cake in the local community. Emma has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Emma is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan Emma has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Noem

texts.en:
Mrs. Noem D., 46 years-old, and her husband, Mr. Davy Srey (pictured together), 44 years-old, live about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1983 and have eight children: two sons and six daughters. Two of the children are married and live outside the family home, three assist their mother at work and the other three attend school.

Noem has been selling vegetables for 31 years. She buys it from farmers and resells in KoKi market. She is applying for her first loan of $800 to build a concrete house foundation and restroom for the family's use.

loans.use: To build a concrete house foundation and restroom.

loans.name: Abel

texts.en: M. Abel is a businessman. He is thirty-eight years old and married with five children in school. He owns a bakery and has been in this business for over eight years. He plans to use his loan to expand his business through purchasing new materials such as baking sets and ingredients, paying his workers, etc. His future plan is to establish bases in different districts to reach a wider market.

loans.use: To purchase new materials.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Sen S., 47, owns a health enterprise producing traditional medicines. She is one of the people living in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. 

To generate a daily profit, Sen finds many types of tree roots from the nearby woods, then processes and combines them as sets of medicines which she sells to patients who are her nearby neighbors. She has a partner in her husband, Yosas, 29, who is a garment factory worker. The couple is blessed with a young child who attends school and depends on their income. 

Sen is taking out her loan to buy a motorcycle, which she will use for her traveling needs.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhom T. (pictured here), aged 57, lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She has nine children: seven sons and two daughters. Two of them are married and live outside the family home, three have full-time employment in Phnom Penh, two attend school and the other two assist their parents in the business.  

Sokhom and her husband have been selling fruit for 20 years.  Because the house where they live is damaged in some parts, Sokhom is asking for a first loan of $1,000 to repair her house. She also plans to use a part of her loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To repair her house.

loans.name: Kit

texts.en: Mrs. Kit R. lives in a medium-sized house from which she operates a small enterprise, selling different types of groceries to the neighbors. She is able to earn approximately $3.50 each day. For another source of income, her husband works as a local chef for wedding parties. Kit has three teenage children who are students in the local public school. She proposes to improve her grocery sale business in order to accrue additional income; thus, she requested a loan of $600 to accumulate more inventory to sell.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en: K. Robinah is a successful businesswoman. She is thirty-five years old and married with one child. She owns a textile boutique. She has run this business for over eight years. She is using the loan to purchase textiles from Zaire, Kenya and within Uganda in order to increase her business stock. Her future plan is to set up another shop.

loans.use: To purchase textiles.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Nelofar Group

texts.en:
Nelofar is the group leader of Nelofar group.She is 30, married with 3 children who are students in the school. She live in Kabul Afghanistan in district 11.She wants to take out her loan for her business of bead work.She has started this work since Taliban regime in order to support her husband and her childern even though, she was educated she couldn't work outside of the house because at that regime all women confined at home and they had no choice to go out and work,but now she has this opportunity to expand her business. She needs the loan for purchasing materials like, different kinds of threads and different colors of bead to continue her business in a better way. She makes nice things using bead like,lockets, breclets and some antique things for house decoration. 
She hopes to have a small shop for this business in the future.

loans.use: buying thread and bead

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is 33 years old and is married with five children. She and her family live in Nyamagabe, in the Southern Province of Rwanda. In this area, Judith owns a shop selling a variety of goods including foodstuffs such as beans, sugar, bananas, etc. Her shop is open from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Judith is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase some additional items like cosmetics goods and some foodstuffs such as sugar, beans, biscuits, cooking oil, etc. With these additional items in her shop, Judith hopes to earn more profits and improve on her savings as well as better providing for her extended family.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for her store

loans.name: Marine

texts.en:
Marine is 23 years old, is single, and she takes care of two dependents who are from members of her family. She lives in Nyaruguru, in the Southern Province of Rwanda and has been in the business of selling foodstuffs including beans, wheat etc since 2006. The hours of her business are from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Marine is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing additional foodstuffs like rice, peas etc. Through accessing this loan, if her expansion plan is successful, Marine will be able to continue working as a self-employed businesswoman with a successful business.

The savings from her additional profits that are not reinvested in her business will allow Marine to take even better care of her two dependents and make big progress in her business.

loans.use: To buy additional foodstuffs for sale.

loans.name: Sang

texts.en: Mrs. Sang P. is 46 years-old and lives in Angk village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns two hectares of land and cultivates rice. She is a widow and has four children.  Two children are employed in a garment factory and two others attend the local public school. This family works very hard with their rice field but they have infertile soil and are far from the irrigation system so they earn less income. Thus, Mrs. Sang P. is applying for a loan to buy more rice seed, fertilizers and fuel for a water pump to support the rice farming.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer and fuel for a water pump.

loans.name: Sokthea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokthea P. (pictured here), 27, and her husband, Mr. Sophal Yorng, 29, have been married since 2005 and have one young daughter. The family is living in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sokthea sells groceries at her home.  She is a tailor as well. Her husband is a garment factory worker. She hopes to expand her business, so that it will be easier for her to respond to her customers' needs. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase fabric for her tailoring business and to buy more grocery items to sell.

loans.use: To purchase fabric for her tailoring business and buy more grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Chim

texts.en:
Chim L. is a 43-year-old and a resident of Phnom Penh city, where she earns a living by cultivating rice and vegetable crops on her plot of land next to her house. 

To help meet with the family’s food needs, her husband operates an animal trade, selling cows. Chim L. has three school-aged children, a married child, and another three who are employed, working in the factory. 

Currently Chim L. faces a problem with irrigating her crops due to the fact that her farm is far from a watering system. To overcome the obstacle, Chim L. has requested a loan to purchase a machine and a pump for watering her crops.

loans.use: To purchase a machine and a pump.

loans.name: Lorna's Group

texts.en:
Lorna S. is from the village of General Balao, Solana, Cagayan. She is 46 years old. Lorna is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Lorna is married and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, Lorna owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $130 a month from this activity.

In 2005, Lorna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Eang

texts.en:
Mr. Eang P. is a villager in Angk village in Kandal province. He is 36 years old. He and his wife, Mrs. Saram Sarun, are farmers who own two hectares of land where they grow rice for their family income. On this land, they face some problems because the field has infertile soil. Also, it is far from an irrigation system, so there is never enough water to support their crop. They do not have enough money to solve these problems. 

Thus, Mr. Eang P. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and fuel to help their field increase its rice production. He is the father of four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local primary school while the other is too young to study or work. His wife is presented in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and fuel to help increase rice production.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinta P. is from the village of Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 49 years old. Jacinta is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Jacinta owns and operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling paint, and also offering painting services in the local community. Jacinta is just starting this business. Before this she was engaged in buying and selling personal products.

In 2009, Jacinta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jacinta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Jacinta is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to further improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Vilma's Group

texts.en:
Vilma B. is from the village of Sinippil, Reina Mercedes, Isabela. She is 45 years old. Vilma is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Vilma is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Vilma owns and operates a business of selling dried fish and vegetables in the market. Aside from that, she also has a hog-raising business. Vilma has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $88 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Vilma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase some hog feed. This will be her 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase some hog feed

loans.name: Azar

texts.en: Azar B. is 24 years old. He is a single. Azar lives in Baku city. This young man has been in this business for 3 years. Now Azar B. needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy the necessary things to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy the necessary things to improve his business

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
