Geraldine V. is a God-fearing and courageous mother. She and her husband help each other to overcome the poverty that impedes their family. She is 40 years old and married to Ronaldo, who is 41 years old and a fisherman. She has three children, all of whom are minors. She lives in the town of Pililia, in Rizal province in the Philippines.

In 2004, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in order to acquire capital for her business. She operates a general store and has started a business providing transportation with a passenger tricycle (motorcycle with side car). As a member of ASHI for almost six years, she has shown very good performance in her credit rating (basis of loans); therefore, she is being trusted by the institution to obtain larger loans. 

This loan is her ninth; she has made good use of past loans to expand her businesses and her income. She has applied for a new loan of 45,000 PHP to buy sacks of rice, charcoal, cooking oil, liquor, cases of soft drinks, canned goods and other supplies, and to pay for transportation expenses.

She dreams of expanding her business into a full-fledged mini-grocery store. She also dreams of sending her children to school until they finish college and find good jobs. Until those dreams happen, she is happy at the way in which ASHI and Kiva have changed her family's life and given them the possibility of making their dreams come true.

loans.use: to buy groceries to sell and to pay transportation expenses.

loans.name: Samouen

texts.en:
Mr. Samouen L. is 37 years old and he lives in Check village in Kandal province. His wife, Mrs. Oret Sok, is a pig breeder, and he is a farmer who owns four hectares of land where he cultivates rice to support the family. On the rice field, this family has some problems, because this is crop growing season, but this family doesn't have enough money to support their field. Moreover, this field has infertile soil and is far from irrigation. 

Thus, Mr. Samouen L. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seeds, fertilizers, and fuel. He is the father of five children, one of whom is a farmer, while another three are enrolled in the local public school, and the other is too young to study or work. His wife is shown in the picture with him.

loans.use: to buy rice seed, fertilizers, and fuel.

loans.name: Terere Group 1, Mukono

texts.en:
(W. Dissan, who appears in the small photo is the leader of his group and the one that was interviewed for the story)

W. Dissan is a hard-working and devoted man and the leader of his lending group in Mukono. He is married with seven children, six of whom go to school. He has a retail shop business that helps him in taking care of his family. Dissan is also a farmer, growing food both for home consumption and to sell and this helps him to have additional income. In the future, Dissan hopes to expand his shop further so that he can make more profits compared to the $26 that he makes every week, approximately. Dissan needs a loan that will help him to restock his shop with more goods and to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: To restock his shop and pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Sokvet

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokvet T. and her husband, Mr. Seangbunq Ngin, live in a small village off of National Road Number Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1998 and have one son and one daughter. The son attends school and the daughter stays at home. Sokvet was not available for the photo, so her mother is pictured instead.  

Sokvet has been a garment factory worker for nine years, while her husband has been driving a motor taxi in Phnom Penh for more than four years. She is requesting a loan of $300 to fill up the land under her house and to build a fence around the house.

loans.use: To fill up the land under her house and build a fence around the house.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng C. is a fish seller who has been experienced in this sector for years. She is 49 years old and is a married mother, caring for two kids who are working in the garment industry. Another one of her children is married and lives away from home. Her husband is a construction foreman. Heng C. has a single son who wants to have a wife and needs to have a wedding party, but Heng C. doesn’t have money yet to have a party. Therefore, she has requested a loan of $700 in order to perform a party, if possible.

loans.use: To perform a wedding party

loans.name: Solita

texts.en:
Solita E. is a good mother to her six children. She is married to her loving spouse, Dionisio, a farmer. They currently live in a nice place, Morong, Rizal. She and her husband work in a farming business. Despite the many challenges in her life, she never gave up fighting against poverty.

She plans to use this loan of PHP 30,000 to expand her farming business and get involved in other businesses for supplementary profits. This loan will be used to buy additional capital for her farming business. During her 6 years as a member of ASHI, she has shown very good performance and has been trusted by ASHI for the length of time she has been involved. Aside from maintaining an excellent performance in repayment, business and attendance at ASHI, she has also attended to her children's needs at home and in school. 

Having this loan will enable her to finally reach her dreams in life: to have a growing business, a good life, and a happy family as well. 

She hopes her children will be able to finish their studies with the help of loans from ASHI, KIVA's field partner. She believes that her business will help her family to rise up and fight against poverty, as well as provide for the educational needs of her children and enable them to have a comfortable house to live in. She is very thankful to ASHI for the continued support of her dreams.

loans.use: To buy additional capital for her farming business.

loans.name: Gerson

texts.en:
Gerson S. is from the village of Camiguin Province. He is 22 years old. Gerson is married and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Gerson owns and operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle services used to transport local community members. Gerson has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately PHP 5,000 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gerson joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gerson has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP 7,000 from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Gerson is requesting a new loan of PHP 10,000, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Gerson from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business.

loans.name: Terere Group 2, Mukono

texts.en: M. Ibrahim is a hardworking man. He is married with school-aged children and has a fishing business that he carries out from Terere site, his home area. Fishing is a job that Ibrahim learnt at an early age due to the fact that it is the major activity in the area in addition to farming. From his fishing business, Ibrahim has been able to buy himself a motorcycle that he uses for transportation services and to carry his fish to the market, as well as to buy himself cows that give him milk to sell. Ibrahim needs a loan to be able to buy a fishing net and to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: To buy a fishing net and pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Estrelita's Group

texts.en:
Estrelita G. is from the village of Brgy, Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 45 years old. Estrelita is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Estrelita is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Estrelita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Estrelita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately PHP 5,000 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Estrelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP 25,000 from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Estrelita is requesting a new loan of PHP 15,000, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Estrelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Mrs. Hem P. is a villager in Check village in Kandal province and she is 49 years old. She is a Khmer cake maker and her husband, Mr. Roeun Vorn, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to support their family. In the field, this family has some problems because they do not have enough money to support their rice field. Moreover the field has infertile soil and is located far from an irrigation system. Thus, Mrs. Hem P. decided to apply for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizers, and fuel to support her rice farming. She is a mother of five children, one of whom is a laborer, another two are farmers, and the others are attending a local public school. Her husband is presented on the right of photo.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds, fertilizers, and fuel to support her rice farming.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. S., 38, is married to Dara, age 49. They both are parents who are blessed with two children who are going to school and dependent on them. Presently S. and her husband depend on income from their annual business whose the main activity is to cultivate various vegetable and fruit crops, which she will harvest and sell to buyers when they are matured. Recently S. doesn’t have enough capital to perform in her crop-planting business, so she decided to look a loan of US $500, and she will buy fertilizers and watermelon seeds to grow.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and watermelon seeds to grow.

loans.name: Ruel

texts.en: Ruel M. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin province. He is 24 years old. Ruel is single. To make a living, Ruel owns & operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle services used to transport passengers in the local community. Ruel has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Ruel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Ruel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Ruel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Eulalia

texts.en: Eulalia Q. is a married woman who supports her family by buying and selling cosmetics and other home supplies. She lives with her husband in Barangay Matuyop, Siaton Negros Oriental. They are able to support their eight children, some of whom are adults and others still at school-age. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her buy-and-sell business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000. Eulalia Q. is now borrowing Php 12,000 so that she can have additional working capital to purchase inventory for her cosmetics and household supplies business. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 18,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Eulalia Q. aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Betty's Group

texts.en:
L. Betty is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is married with three children ages 16-22 years old, who are all in school, and she takes care of her siblings.

Betty has a retail shop on the Lugazi market street and although there is a lot of competition from other sellers, she is able to make 50,000/= (shillings) as weekly profits that help her sustain her family, with the help of her husband.

Betty is so grateful for her loans because they enable her to have increased stock as well as having quality products for sale. She sells carpets and bags in her shop plus belts and she would need a loan to be able to restock her shop.

loans.use: To buy more carpets and bags for increased stock.

loans.name: Mean

texts.en: Mean S., age 63, is a married woman and the mother of four children. Two attend the local public school and other two are employees in a sewing cloth industry. Mean S. is a cultivator who plants rice and vegetable crops. She has a partner in her husband, who assists her in the farming business. In the paste, Mean S. hired a neighbor’s cow to allow her physical labor in plowing her farmland and she right now wants to reduce this fee by asking for a loan to purchase a couple of cows, which she will use them to alleviate her in plowing farmland.

loans.use: To purchase a couple of cows.

loans.name: Manuel's Group

texts.en:
Manuel N. is from the village of Lalog 2, Luna, Isabela. He is 43 years old. Manuel is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Manuel is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Manuel owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and for sale. Manuel has been engaged in his business for over 8 years and earns approximately PHP 3,000 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Manuel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Manuel is requesting a new loan of PHP 6,000, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Manuel from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay his child's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.

loans.name: Lem

texts.en:
Mr. Lem Lay and his wife, Mrs. Sarun H., live along National Road number one about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1986 and have three children: a daughter, who is a garment factory worker, and two sons, one who is married and lives in separate home and the other who is a mason. Lem is not in the photo; his wife is pictured instead. 

Lem and his wife have been farming since 1986. In addition, Lem is also a fisherman. He has already received one Kiva loan through Maxima. He now is requesting his second loan of $1,000 to purchase pesticides, seeds and fertilizer to continue expanding his farm.

loans.use: To use for farming.

loans.name: Bunthat

texts.en: Mr. Bunthat C. is a villager in York Bath village in Kandal province and he is 43 years old. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. In the rice field, he faces a problem because he does not have enough money to buy fertilizers and pesticides. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. His wife, Mrs.Chan Noeun Ya, is vegetable seller in the local market. Mr. Bunthat C. is a father of three children, all of whom are attending a local public school. His wife is shown in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides for his rice field.

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en: The two persons shown in the picture are Mrs. Chhorn P., 48, and her husband, age 42. They currently live in Siem Reap Province. Chhorn P. earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she also cultivates a rice crop, while her husband is a rice farmer and also a firewood seller. They have two school-aged children. Chhorn P. will use her loan to grow rice.

loans.use: To grow rice.

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita E., from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province, is 51 years old, married and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Estelita has owned and operated a sari-sari (variety) retail shop for over two years, earning approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Estelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a loan of 4000 PHP to be used to expand the business, she plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Chanthol

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthol O., 43, and her husband, Mr. Chansithy Thorn, 46, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1990 and have four children: three sons and one daughter.

Chanthol has been a silk weaver for 30 years, a skill she learned from her mother, while her husband has been a motor taxi driver for eight years. She wants to supplement their income by starting a pig-raising business and is therefore requesting her first loan of $600 to purchase piglets and pig food.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food

loans.name: Helenita

texts.en: Helenita O. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 56 years old, is married, and has one adult child. Helenita owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling coconuts in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Helenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria C. is a 59-year-old married woman who supports her family by running a food vending business, also known as a carinderia. She lives in Brgy Canaway, Siaton Negros Oriental with her husband, and they still support their four children, some of whom are adults now and have already graduated from college with the help of NWTF-Project Dungganon.

Victoria has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions both with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her carinderia, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 12,000.

Victoria C. is now requesting Php 19,000 for additional working capital for her carinderia. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Victoria C. aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a community member who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Fe's Group

texts.en:
Fe M., from the town of Fugu Echague, is the 47-year-old group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Fe M.'s group.

Fe, who is married and has three school-aged children, owns and operates a weaving business whose main income comes from making and selling general woven products to tourists and local community members. Engaged in her business for over two years, she earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Fe joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase raw materials to expand product offerings, she plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to expand product offerings

loans.name: Margie

texts.en:
Margie is a rice grower. She currently tills a 3-hectare (7.5-acre) rice field, which she is now preparing for planting.

A 33-year-old married woman, Margie has children who go to school. She does her best to make her farm productive because it is the sole source of her family’s income. It’s where she gets income for food, clothes and her children’s education.

Margie currently needs inputs for her farm. She is applying for a loan of Php 7,000 from CEVI. If granted, the loan will be used for fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Bobby

texts.en:
Bobby works hard for his family. He has been married to Marie since 2004 and they now have a 4-year-old child.

Bobby is into hog-raising and also sells calamansi (citrus fruit) to earn extra income. Bobby wants to expand his businesses and to start doing that, he applied for a loan of Php 7,000 from CEVI which would help increase his working capital. The loan will be used for hog-feed, piglets and additional calamansi fruits to sell.

loans.use: To buy hog-feed, piglets and additional calamansi fruits to sell

loans.name: Edgardo

texts.en:
47-year-old Edgardo needs additional capital for his business. He manages a 3-hectare (7.5-acre) rice field and is involved in a hog-raising business.

Edgardo wants to do well in his business so he can provide for his family’s needs. His wife, Mary Grace, and their three children are what give him comfort and joy at the end of the day.

Edgardo applied for a loan of Php 7,000 from CEVI. This loan will help him achieve an abundant harvest and expand his hog-raising business.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and to expand his hog-raising business

loans.name: Elizabeth's Group

texts.en: Elizabeth S. is from the village of Padul, Solana, Cagayan. She is 33 years old and is the group leader of a ten-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Elizabeth is married and has three young children. She owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Elizabeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her third from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mugandu Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
N. David is the leader of his lending group in Kihihi. He is 28 years old and married with one child only one year old.

David is a businessman involved in agriculture. He keeps animals for meat and for sale and the challenge he has is that animal vaccines are in short supply and hence more expensive.

David has operated from Kyogo – Kinaaba village for two years and he is able to make 20,000/= as profits every week. He hopes to continue having high quality breeds of animals so that his standard of living will improve. He also hopes to have a family motorcycle to help with transport.

David mostly trades and rears goats and he hopes his first loan will help him increase his income and foster business growth. He is such a social and hardworking man and needs a loan to be able to buy more goats.

loans.use: To buy more goats to sell

loans.name: Nicel

texts.en: Nicel H. is a 33-year-old married woman who lives in Barangay Panaquiao, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living through her general store, RTW, and buying and selling rice. RTW, or "Ready To Wear", is the selling of used clothing which is a very popular business among Project Dungganon members. Nicel’s husband, Cyrus, 35 years old, works as a laborer in a sugarcane plantation. They have five children who are between 2 and 12 years old. All of her children are still attending school and also help in running the business and with household chores. Nicel joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by running her businesses and now earns an average monthly income of Php 4,500. Nicel is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 14,000 was used to fund her businesses, and it had a positive impact in both the businesses and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 6th loan of Php 14,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her businesses. Nicel is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her RTW and rice businesses

loans.name: Sitha

texts.en:
Mr. Sitha H. (pictured with his daughter), is a widower with two sons and four daughters. Two of his daughters are garment factory workers. He lives in a village about 10 miles outside of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sitha is a motor taxi driver. In the past, he used to drive siklo (a bicycle with a compartment in the front to carry goods and people). He now is requesting a loan of 600 USD to purchase a motorcycle for his son to launch a motor taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his son to launch a motor taxi business.

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida C. is a 52-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy Panaquiao, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store, locally known as a 'sari-sari' store.

Nida’s husband Eduardo is 54 years old and works as a laborer in sugarcane plantation, and they have 6 children who are between 9 and 31 years old. Some of her children have work while the others are still attending school and also helping to run the business.

Nida joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 in the hope that she would be able to help improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income, earning an additional Php 4,000 from her business activities.

Nida is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 12,000 was used to fund operations of her sari-sari store, and it had a positive impact in both the business and improving the family’s living conditions. Now she is requesting her 5th loan, in the amount of Php 12,000, which she intends to use on general store business. Nida is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz G. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old. Luz is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Luz owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling souvenir items like printed shirts and key holders in the local community. Luz has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Luz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Luz is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Luz from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Saman's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Saman M. is the group leader of six members who all live in Chrouy Chrey village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Knoun Mul, are farmers who own 1 hetare of land to cultivate rice on to earn a living. In the rice field, they face an obstacle because their field has infertile soil. Additionally, their field is far from the irrigation system.

Thus, Mrs. Saman M. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and fuel to pump water to support the rice field. She is the mother of six children, one of whom is a driver while two others are laborers. One is attending the local school and the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and fuel to pump water to support the rice field

loans.name: Ma. Cynthia

texts.en: Cynthia is a tenant on a 2-hectare rice farm. She is a widow and has five children to take care of. Her oldest, who is 27 years old, helps her on the farm. Cynthia needs additional capital so she has applied for a loan of Php 7,000 from CEVI. She will use this loan to purchase farm inputs such as seeds, fertilizer, and others.

loans.use: buying farm inputs for her rice farm

loans.name: Turtogtoh

texts.en:
Turtogtoh is 43 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent.
Turtogtoh operates a consumer goods trading business with the help of his sister. She lives and works in Tuva Republic and is responsible for selling products at her rented stall at a local market. Turtogtoh imports consumer goods and exports them to Tuva Republic. He sells a variety of household items to the residents of Tuva Republic. He has had developed his business into a stable operation and has established a strong customer base.
In order to expand his business, Turtogtoh began to sell construction materials along with consumer goods. With his business earnings, he has bought a house and some electrical appliances such as a TV, computer, Canon printer, etc. In the future, he wants to have his own working place in Mongolia. He is a very hardworking man and attributes his success to his good accounting skills. He is focused on the future and says, “I want to provide my children with a happy life.” He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase construction materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials

loans.name: Rutendere Group A, Kihihi

texts.en:
T. Geofrey is a married man with five children aged between 2 and 15 years. He also takes care of his mother. He is a hardworking man with two businesses: he grows, buys and sells, and he also has a motorcycle business. He has been in business for 15 years at Butogota trading center, and is able to make 50,000 UGX profit every week.
Geofrey lacks sufficient capital for his businesses to thrive since most of his earnings are taken up with the payment of school fees. Geofrey is requesting a loan to buy more coffee for resale since this will expand his business and increase sales and profits. He is grateful for his loans.
In the future he would like to convert his retail business to wholesale, have a wholesale shop, and build a permanent house for his family.

loans.use: To buy more coffee for resale

loans.name: Ret

texts.en:
Mrs. Ret M. (pictured here) and her husband, Mr. Khorn Porm, live on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. The have been married since 1975 and have 7 children: 5 sons and 2 daughters. One of was married and lives outside the family home, two sons are construction workers; one daughter works in garment factory and the other attend school. 

Mrs. Ret M. has been a silk weaver since she was sixteen years old. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village who then in turns them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband collects palm juice for sale in his village and to make palm sugar.

Ret used to ask for Kiva loan one time already. She now is requesting another loan in the amount of $600 to put concrete her house foundation and repair the house where she lives.

loans.use: To put concrete in her house foundation and repair the house where she lives

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila P. is from the village of Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 53 years old. Mila is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Mila owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Mila has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Mila is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Mila from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en: Evangeline manages a 2-hectare rice field and a hog-raising business. She is 40 years old, married, and has children. She is happy to share that her business is currently going well. She wants to maintain its status so she can provide for her family’s growing needs. She applied for a loan of PHp 7,000 from CEVI. This loan will be used for farm inputs and feed for the hogs.

loans.use: farm inputs and hog feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Salmon

texts.ru: Алимов Салмон проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 34 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Алимов Салмон имеет высшее образование по специальности "Педагог". Растениеводством занимается более 5 лет. Алимов Салмон сажает картошку и собирая вывозит на рынок. В этом ему помогают родственники. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
A. Salmon lives in the Shahrituz region. He's thirty-four years old, married and has five children. A. has a university degree qualifying him as a teacher. He has grown potatoes for more than five years. Later, with then help of his family, he sells it at the market. He's asking for a loan in order to buy seeds and mineral fertilizers

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Badamhand

texts.en:
Badamhand is 45 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Zavhan province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian tent. Her son is 24 years old and works as a welder in a private company while her younger son is 18 years old and attends university. Unfortunately, her husband is handicapped; he stays home and needs care every single day.

Badamhand operates a clothes-making business at her home in her town. She started her business operation after working as a dressmaker at a state factory from 1985-1996 (until it closed down). During this time she gained much experience and skill in her trade. Today, her business is well known throughout her community and her customers like her business because she can produce products specific to their needs. She both designs and produces all of the clothes, 'ger' cover and curtains with the help of her sister, using 2 sewing machines that she bought.

With her business profit she has been able to start building a workplace and a house which has not been completed yet. Moreover she was able to pay for her children's education. Badamhand works hard to grow her business and provide quality products to her customers. Her business is very important to her as it is the only source of income for her and her family. She says, "For the future I want to expand my business and am planning to buy new equipment and hire two more assistants.”

Badamhand is requesting a 600,000 tugrug (~420 USD) loan to purchase fabrics and materials to sew more products.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and materials to make more products.

loans.name: Leonardo

texts.en:
Leonardo D. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 38 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Leonardo owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling garlands and peanuts in the local community. Leonardo has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2009, Leonardo joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Leonardo is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be his third from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Leang

texts.en:
Mr. Leang L. and his wife, Mrs. Nao Soeun, have been married since 1990. They have two children: one son and one daughter, both in school. The family lives in a small village off National Road Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh City.
 
Leang has been a TV and radio repairman for more than sixteen years, while his wife has been a garment factory worker for more than eight years. He has one previous Kiva loan and now is requesting his second loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorcycle for his children to drive to school and to expand his house.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for his children to drive to school and to expand his house

loans.name: Fortunata

texts.en:
Fortunata Y. is a married woman who supports her family by operating a food-vending business, selling frozen foods and running a general store. She lives in Bollos St., Brgy Boyco, Bayawan City, Negros Oriental, with her husband and their school-aged child.
Fortunata has been a member of Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, since 1996. She has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her various businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 3,800 PHP.
Fortunata Y. is now borrowing 12,000 PHP to expand into other areas of food vending, including selling barbecue (also known as inalsal). This will be her sixteenth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 10,000 PHP was paid off well within its term, and was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Fortunata Y. aspires to improve her family’s living conditions and ensure its future wellbeing.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To expand into other areas of food vending

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Thorn P. is a villager in Choeng Prey 3 village in Kandal province and she is 48 years old. She is a fruit seller and her husband, Mr. Chork Porn, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which he cultivates rice to support their living. Her husband is shown with her in the photo.

This couple has five children, three of whom are workers in a garment factory, another is attended the local public school, and the other is unemployed. Thus, Mrs. Thorn P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her child to be a taxi motorbike driver. She hopes to increase their income and improve the family living with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her child to be a taxi motorbike driver

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Batjargal

texts.en:
Batjargal is 28 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Zavhan province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". He operates a transportation service and meat-trading business with the help of his wife in their town.

Batjargal's wife is mainly responsible for selling the meat and he is responsible for transporting people's goods and luggage from and to the countryside and center of the province. He transports 1-2 times per month during the warm weather and 2 times per season during cold weather.

He started his business with the help of his father in 2000. With years of business experience, he was able to start his own transportation business in 2007. He manages the finances of the business and advises his wife on the day-to-day operations. They have gained much experience and are planning to continue and maintain their business for the future. With their business gain they were able to make the remaining payment on their new truck and bought a carpet for their home.

For the future they want to build a house for themselves. Batjargal says, “I want to save enough money for my children's education while they are young. Also I would like to buy a car for myself.” He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan to purchase fodder to sell to herders in remote areas.

loans.use: to purchase fodder to resell

loans.name: Baryaly Norya Group

texts.en:
This is the BaryA. Norya group. There are five members in this group. The group leader is Naqebullah, and he is a married man. He lives with his family and he wants to take a loan for his business of general store. He has to work hard and earn money for the completion of house expenses. He wants to purchase additional materials for his shop and make it vast.

Norya is a tailor and works hard to earn money for the completion of her family’s requirements. She needs to buy a new sewing machine for her shop because she has lots of problems with the old one she has. Besides, she wants to hire a student to support this business and to enlarge the business. Shokorya wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of car-part selling shop. He wants to expand and develop his business. BaryA. wants to take a loan for his business of painting. He paints houses according to the desire of the owner. He needs the money because he wants to improve for his business. And the other member, Najebullah, wants to take a loan for his business of video shop. He would like to expand his business.

They are all thankful to the Kiva lenders from their support.

loans.use: to expand their businesses

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy M. is a married woman who supports her family by operating a candy-making and food processing business. She lives in Prk 6 Kawitan Sta. Catalina, Negros Oriental with her husband who also helps her in running the business.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her candy-making and food processing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 10,800.

Juvy M. is now borrowing Php 16,500 so that she can expand her business and also buy more of the ingredients she needs. By purchasing materials in higher volume, she can increase her profit margin. This will be her 7th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 14,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Juvy M. aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Pinky

texts.en:
Pinky P. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 31 years old. Pinky is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Pinky owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling island souvenir like fish key holders, decorations and printed tshirts  in the local community. Pinky has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Pinky joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pinky has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Pinky is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Pinky from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en: Vilma G. is a 63-year-old married woman who lives in Barangay Panaquiao, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a food-vending business. Vilma’s husband, David, is a pensioner who now helps in running the business. They have six children between the ages of 19 and 42 years. Some of her children have started their own families and some remain at home and assist their parents in the business. Vima joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 with the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by selling her foods and now earns an average monthly income of Php 4,000. Vilma is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 11,000 was used to fund operations of her food-vending business and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now Vilma is borrowing Php 13,000 as her 5th loan which she intends to use for her food vending business. She is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Lucila

texts.en:
Lucila G., 62, is a hardworking single mom. She makes sure that she earns enough so that her two children can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for five years. Aside from owning a store, she also manages rooms for rent.

Lucila has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than three years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow 10 times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy stock for her variety store.  Both of her businesses let her earn a combined profit of 13,000 Philippine pesos per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying assorted canned goods, snacks, toiletries and hygiene products.

She dreams that her business will expand to become a mini grocery someday and she prays for an abundant and peaceful life ahead. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying assorted canned goods, snacks, toiletries and hygiene products

loans.name: Rutendere Group B, Kihihi

texts.en:
T. Mourice is the leader of her lending group in Kihihi. She is a social and approachable married lady with four children aged 15 to 3 years as she also takes care of three orphans.

Mourice is a businesswoman who has been involved in trading used clothes from Butogota trading centre for four years now. She is able to make 50,000/= as weekly profits although she is faced with a challenge of inadequate capital hence little stock. She says that she has been able to attract her customers because of the quality clothes in her stock and she would like her business to expand so that she could begin advertising on radio stations in her area.

Mourice’s dream is to have a bigger and permanent house for her family. She needs a loan to be able to buy more used clothing for her stock.

loans.use: To buy more used clothing to sell

loans.name: Elbegzaya

texts.en:
Elbegzaya is 47 years old and lives with her daughter in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter is 26 years old and works in the Physics and Technology Institute with a monthly salary of 270,000 tugrugs (about $190). 

Elbegzaya manages a consumer goods trading business out of a rented stall in her town. She began her business operation in 2003 after working as a clerk for seven years. She sells a wide variety of consumer and household goods imported from China. At first she sold her goods in the streets, where it is very harsh and uncomfortable. Then, with several years of successful business operation, she was able to rent a stall at the Bumbugur trading center, which is one of the most crowded and popular markets. 

Now her working capital is 1,500,000 tugrugs (about $1,050) and she has built a consistent operation over the years. She has developed a loyal base of customers and works hard to adapt her business to their needs. Elbegzaya has used her success to make repairs to her home and improve the quality of life for her family. She is focused on the future and says, "I want to improve the quality of my family life.” 

Elbegzaya is requesting a 1,100,000 tugrug loan to purchase more products from China.

loans.use: To purchase household items to resell

loans.name: Ropert

texts.en: Ropert L. is a single man who supports himself and his family by selling different kinds of herbal products. He lives in Barangay Binicuil, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. Ropert has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved his living conditions with the help of his loans from NWTF and through his own efforts. By working hard in selling his herbal products business, he is gradually making his family more economically stable. He now earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000. Ropert is now borrowing Php 9,000 so that he can buy additional products to sell. This will be his 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. His previous loan of Php 6,000, which he paid off well within its term, was just another step in his journey towards economic freedom. Ropert aspires to elevate his family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy additional products to sell

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion P., 54, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Bernard Pasalbon, she is blessed with six children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn in their family business so that their family can have a better life. They have been selling dried fish for several years.  Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 4,500 per month.

Concepcion has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than three years now. She regularly attends the weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow nine times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy added fish stock for her business.

Now, with your help, Concepcion would like to apply for a PHP 16,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying more dried fish to sell. She dreams that her family will someday have better living conditions through the help of her expanding business.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Sharofat

texts.ru: Сафарова Шарофат проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 48 лет. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Сафарова Шарофат занимается растениеводством  более 3 лет. Она сажает картошку. Во всем этом ей помогает муж. Целью кредита является закуп семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Sharofat S. lives in the Shahrituz district. She is 48 years old, married and has 5 children. Sharofat has been involved in agriculture for over 3 years. She grows potatoes. Her husband helps her with this business. She is obtaining this loan in order to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Enhtuvshin

texts.en:
Enhtuvshin is 32 years old and lives with her mother and two children in a house in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter, Namuun, is 9 years old and is a secondary school student while her husband works and lives in Korea. Her husband went to Korea as a contracted worker and has stayed for a total of four years now. 

Enhtuvshin operates a clothes trading and household goods selling business out of a rented stall at a local market in her town. She started her business in 2005 after working as a dressmaker for several years and has gained much business experience over the years. Now her working capital is 4,000,000 tugrugs (about $2,800) with a daily profit of 100,000 tugrugs (about $70). 

Enhtuvshin is a very hardworking person and is always working toward her future goals. She says, "I want to expand my business for the future and be able to pay for my children's education until my husband comes back home." 

She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase clothes

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita M., 23, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Pany M. Jr., a vendor, she is blessed with one child who is still not of school age.

Carmelita makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been involved in selling display racks for more than ten years, what was once a family business of her parents.

Carmelita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends the weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow several times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy equipment from wholesalers. Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 12,900.

Now, with your help, Carmelita would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying additional racks from wholesalers.

Carmelita dreams of having a good business with an adequate amount of wealth and good health for her family. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional display racks from wholesalers

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria T. is from the village of Mambajao , Camiguin province. She is 49 years old. Victoria is married and has five adult children. Victoria owns & operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products in the local community. Victoria has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2009, Victoria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Victoria has successfully repaid her first loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. That loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Victoria is requesting a second loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita M., 47, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Mateo M., a jeepney driver, she is blessed with five children.

Margarita makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own video game rental business for more than a year.

Margarita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends the weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow four times in CCT’s cooperative.

Margarita is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy games and equipments needed for her video game business.  Her business lets her earn an additional profit of PHP 7,200 per month.

Now, with your help, Margarita would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying an optical mouse, electronic cables and a television.

Margarita dreams that someday her business will expand to become a successful Internet café so that their living conditions will improve as well.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy an optical mouse, electronic cables and a television

loans.name: Hermenia

texts.en: Hermenia M. is a married woman who supports her family by operating a general store and selling barbecue chicken and pork. She lives in Ballos Sts., Bayawan City, Negros Oriental with her husband, who also helps her in running the business. They have two school-aged children. Hermenia has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1996 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and barbecue-vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,000. Hermenia is now borrowing Php 12,000 as additional working capital for her general store and barbecue vending businesses. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Hermenia aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Soth

texts.en:
Mrs. Soth Y. lives in Kaoh Reah Kraom village in Kandal province and she is 61 years old. She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) field on which she grows crops to support her family living.

In this crop field, Mrs. Soth Y. now faces a problem because her field is far from the irrigation system and she does not have money to support it. Thus, Mrs. Soth Y. decided to request a loan to buy a water pump to support her field to increase her crop yield.

Mrs. Soth Y. is a widow with a child who is a farmer too.

loans.use: To buy a water pump to irrigate her field

loans.name: Melita

texts.en:
Melita R. D., 55, is making sure that her children have enough provisions for their daily needs. Now living as a single mother, she was married to Melonio D. until he passed away, leaving Melita with their three children. In order for her family to survive, Melita has been managing her own parlor business for ten years.

Melita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends the weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow nine times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy equipment and haircare products for her parlor business.

Now, with your help, Melita would like to obtain a PHP 30,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying assorted haircare and grooming products for her parlor business.

Aside from good family relationships, Melita dreams of a better life for her family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy assorted haircare and grooming products for her parlor business

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 34 years old and is married with three children with ages 3, 6 and 8 years. Grace and her family live in Nyaruguru, in the Southern Province of Rwanda. Here Grace has owned a shop since 2002. Her shop is open from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. every day.

Grace is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her shop. She plans to purchase some additional goods which seem to be highly in demand by a large number of her customers. With those additional goods such as rice, beans, corn flour, cooking oil, etc, Grace hopes that her profits will be increased.

With these profits, Grace will be able to use some in taking care of her family and some will be used to invest in other sources of income. 

Through accessing this Kiva loan, Grace has a hope for the future.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for her store

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty C. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin province. She is 50 years old. Betty is married and has an adult child. To make a living, Betty runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Betty has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Betty joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Betty is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Betty from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en: Amelita P. is a 39-year-old married woman who lives in Mohon Barangay Binicuil, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a photocopying business. She currently has four photocopiers and wants to use her loan to put a down payment on a fifth. Amelita’s husband, Demetrio, works as a part-time driver and also helps the business. They have six children between the ages of 4 and 13. Four of her children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores. Amelita P. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 with the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family.
