With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, a Kiva partner, she has been able to increase their family income. Now she earns an average monthly income of 30,000 Philippine pesos from her business activities. Amelita P. is a NWTF-PD member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 19,500 was used to fund operations of her photocopier business and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing, for her 10th loan, the amount of Php 20,500, which she intends to use as a down payment for an additional photocopier unit. Amelita P. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Down payment for one additional photocopier

loans.name: Gundsambuu

texts.en:
Gundsambuu is 20 years old and lives with his mother and two younger brothers in the Zavhan province in Mongolia. He and his family live in a Mongolian traditional nomadic tent called “ger.” His mother had a very serious car accident and became handicapped. She needs care every single day. His mother receives 54,000 tugrugs (about $38) of allowances per month, which is too low for a living. 

Gundsambuu operates a wooden product making business with the help of his younger brother in his town. He started his business in 2007 after his high school graduation. He made his decision based on his difficult life of taking care of his mother and paying for his brothers' education. He makes all kinds of furniture using black wood and cedar wood, which makes the wooden products very strong and hard. In 2009 he began to operate his own wooden product making business using his tools purchased from China. 

He has been quite successful in conducting his business and has established a strong customer base. He is very hardworking and always looks for ways to grow his business. With his business earnings, he was able to buy a new cover for his ger, which enabled his home to be more warm than before. For the future, Altansukh plans to expand and improve his business in order to have enough treatment money for his mother. He truly wants his mother to stand by using a walking stick.  

He is requesting a 500,000 tugrug loan to purchase cedar wood and other materials used to make his products.

loans.use: To purchase cedar wood and other materials

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic O., age 42, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Flaviano O., a maintenance painter, they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn in order for their family to have a better life. She has been making and selling industrial bags for five years.

Marivic has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings, and she pays her weekly dues consistently. Due to her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow five times in CCT's Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues, because she uses the borrowed money to buy the raw materials needed for her bag making business. Her business lets her earn an extra profit of 3800 PHP per month.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a 12,000 PHP loan. By buying different raw materials needed for her bag making business, the loan amount will be used as a source of added capital in her expanding business.

She dreams that someday she will see her children with their own professions and with better living conditions than what they experience today.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy different raw materials needed for her bag making business

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raquel V., 29, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Roy V., a tricycle driver, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been direct selling different cosmetics and branded women’s clothes for more than a year.

Raquel has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT), a Kiva partner, for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow six times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy more cosmetic and apparel products for resale. Her business lets her earn an extra profit of 7,600 Philippine pesos per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital by buying more clothes and assorted cosmetic products as added stock for her direct-selling business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can finance her children's education until they graduate from college. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying more clothes and assorted cosmetic products as added stock for her direct-selling business

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva T. is a 49-year old married woman who lives in the Barangay of Binicuil in Kabankalan City, located in the province of Negros Occidental. She earns her living by selling herbal products.

Eva’s husband Edgardo works as a juice retailer.  They have three children between the ages of 14 and 20.  One is already working while the other is still looking for job.  The youngest of her children is currently going to school and also helps his parents in the business as part of his daily chores.

Eva T. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 to help her husband improve the quality of life  their family. With the help of such loans to start her business, she has been able to increase their family income. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 20,000.

Eva T. is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 11,500 was used to fund operations of her business and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 6th loan, the amount of Php 12,000, which she intends to use as additional working capital for her business.  Eva T. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. During the visit for data and picture, all of her recent product stock had already been delivered to her buyers but delivery receipts were available for proof of business.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To provide additional working capital for herbal products business.

loans.name: Karukara Group A, Kihihi

texts.en: Festo T. is the leader of his lending group in Kihihi. He is 42 years old and married with six children ranging in age from 4 to 19 and who all attend primary or secondary school. Festo is a business man who trades produce in the Rukakara trading centre.  He has been in this business for five years and he is able to earn about 400,000 UGX profits every month. Festo says that his returns would be better if he had enough capital since he knows how to treat his customers well. He hopes to expand his business into the main town of Kihihi where there are better services and earning potential. This will help him better provide for the education of his children. He needs a loan to be able to improve his business by buying more produce like coffee and matooke for resale. Matooke is a meal consisting of steamed green plantain and is one of the national dishes of Uganda.

loans.use: To buy more coffee and matooke for resale.

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
Carol R. is a 55-year-old married woman who lives in Barangay Manalungon of Santa Catalina in the province of Negros Oriental. She earns her living by vending fish and operating a general store business.

Carol’s husband Edmund is 55 years old and a fisherman.  They have three children, two who help their father in his fishing business.  Both Carol and her husband dream to improve their living conditions and to sustain the needs of her family.

Carol R. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 5,000 from her business activities.

Carol R. is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 5,000 was used to fund operations of her fish vending, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 12th loan, the amount of Php 10,000, which she intends to use to buy supplies for her fish vending and general store. Carol is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her fish vending business.

loans.name: Guluzar

texts.en: Guluzar was born in 1953. She is married and has 5 children. Bakhshaliyev's family lives in Baku city. Guluzar B. has been in this business for 7 years. Now she needs a loan of 1600 AZN to buy goods to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy goods

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita Pateñ, age 52, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Jaime Pateno, a carpenter and a construction worker, they are blessed with two children. She helps her husband earn income so their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for six years.

Nenita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy additional stock for her variety store.   She earns about PHP 6,000 per month profit from her business.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying added stocks like assorted snacks, beverages, canned goods, toiletries and mobile phone credits.  She dreams that her store will grow, so her family can have a better life in the near future. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy stock for her store like assorted snacks, beverages, canned goods, toiletries and mobile phone credits

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina P. is from the village of Guinsiliban on the island province of Camiguin. She is 40 years old and married with 7 school-aged children. Rosalina is going to start providing motorcycle services, transporting passengers in the local community, for a business managed by her husband. Rosalina also has a mini sari-sari store as a source of income.

Rosalina joined HSPFI in 2009 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a 5000 PHP loan, and is now requesting her second HSPFI loan, for 6000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Sam Oeurn

texts.en:
Mr. Sam Oeurn S. lives in Kaoh Reah Kraom village in the Kandal province. He is 63 years old. He and his wife, Mrs. Yen Machh, are grocers in the local village to support their family. Although their business is doing well, they still earn less income than they need to support the family. 

In order to expand this business and improve the family's living conditions, Mr. Sam Oeurn S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery products to resell. This couple does not have children. His wife is on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products and support their farming

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma R., 48, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Renato R., a direct-selling vendor, she is blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. Both of them have been selling different kinds of furniture for several years.

Norma has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends the weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow nine times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy raw materials for her furniture business. Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 4,500 per month.

Now, with your help, Norma would like to obtain a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying products like chairs, tables and mosquito nets.

Norma dreams that they will have more clients so that they can earn more for their children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products like chairs, tables and mosquito nets

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer J., 33, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. Married to Bonifacio J., a factory worker, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing a bike rental business for some time.

Jennifer has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends the weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow seven times in CCT’s cooperative.

Jennifer is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand her bicycle renting business. Her business lets her earn an extra profit of PHP 3,800 per month.

Now, with your help, Jennifer would like to obtain a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying assorted bicycle parts.

Jennifer dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can earn more and send her children to a better school.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy assorted bicycle parts

loans.name: Magbontho Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Magbontho' group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the town of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. With the help of this loan, the can add more goods to their current stock, make more sales and profit, and consequently improve their living conditions.

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Ballay K. who is second from left in the photo. The 37-year-old Ballay is married and has 4 children. Her husband is a businessman and 2 of her children are attending primary school; 1 is in secondary school and 1 is a teacher. For more than 12 years now, Ballay has been selling groundnuts (peanuts), rice and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil). With her share of the loan, Ballay will buy bags of rice, bags of groundnuts, and gallons of palm oil.

loans.use: Buy bags of rice, bags of groundnuts, and gallons of palm oil

loans.name: Abubakr

texts.ru: Очилдиев Абубакр проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 25 лет. Женат, имеет одного ребенка. Очилдиев Абубакр занимается растениеводством более 6 лет. Он вносит минеральные удобрения и готовит почву для весених посевов. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Abubakr O. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 25 years old, married and has one child. Abubakr has been involved in agriculture for over 6 years. He uses mineral fertilizers and prepares the ground for the spring planting season. He is obtaining this loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Karukara Group B, Kihihi

texts.en:
T. Norbert is 30 years old and married with three children aged 4 years, 2 years, and 1 month.

Nobert has traded in the buying and selling of produce from Rukarara Cell for four years and he is able to make 240,000/= as profits every month, although his business is much affected by the fluctuating prices of agricultural produce.

Nobert is successful in business because of his good customer care and trustworthiness and he would like to have more investments of the same sort in much bigger towns. He also hopes to educate his children with the best of education plus have good health.

Norbert is a hardworking man and he needs a loan to be able to buy more matooke (steamed green plantain), coffee and Irish potatoes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more matooke, coffee and Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: Paz

texts.en:
Paz B., 62, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. Married to Diego B., a vendor, she is blessed with one child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been selling assorted meats for several years now.

Paz has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends the weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow ten times in CCT’s cooperative.

Paz is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy different kinds of meat for her store. Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 4,700 per month.

Now with your help, Paz would like to obtain a PHP 16,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying pork and other meats from wholesale butchers.

Paz dreams that her business will continue to improve with more loyal customers.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy pork and other meats from wholesale butchers

loans.name: Angie

texts.en:
Angie G., 41 is married to Jaime G., a jail officer, are are blessed with three children. She makes sure she helps her husband earn enough money so their family can have a better life.  She has been selling prepaid mobile phone credits for more than a year.

Angie has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow six times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed by buying load credits for prepaid subscribers.   Her business lets her earn an additional profit of PHP 4,500 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 14,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying mobile phone prepaid load credits.

She dreams that her business will help her save enough moneyfor the future schooling of her children. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying mobile phone prepaid load credits

loans.name: Theodore

texts.en:
Theodore is 36 years old and is married with one kid of 3 months. He and his family live in Gakenke, in the Northern Province of Rwanda.

For one year, Theodore has been in the business of selling drinks made from sorghum and he employs two people in his business. The hours of his business are from 6 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Theodore is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of adding to his capital and purchasing more sorghum, as the demand of his customers keeps growing.

With this loan, Theodore hopes that his number of customers will increase as well as his profits, which in turn will help him and his devoted wife to build their own house.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials for making drinks

loans.name: We Heart Dae Group

texts.en:
These are members of 'We Heart Dae' group from the township of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesspeople who want a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. 

The leader of the group is 40-year-old Fatu K. on the left in the photo. Fatu, who is married to a businessman and the mother of 4 children, sells market food like onions, 'margi' (used to give sauce a sweet taste), rice, and sugar. Fatu has 20 years of experience in this business. With her share of this loan, she will buy 'margi' in cartons, bags of onions, and bags of rice to add to her business.

loans.use: Buy margi in cartons, bags of onions, and bags of rice to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Mr. Neang  P. lives in  the Ampil village in Kandal province. He is 27 years old and lives with his family. He is a farmer who owns land and cultivates both rice and vegetables. Although he works hard, he earns a minimal income to support his family. He now faces an obstacle because he does not have enough money to buy vegetable seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides to support his farming. 
In order to deal this problem, Mr. P. is asking for a loan to assist his vegetable growing.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seed, fertilizers, and pesticides to support his farming.

loans.name: Shirley's Group

texts.en:
Shirley M. is from the village of Bantay, Solana, Cagayan. She is 44 years old. Shirley is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Shirley is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Shirley owns & operates a business in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Shirley has been in her business for over one year and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Shirley joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shirley has successfully repaid her previous loan from ASKI. Shirley is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of the borrower's children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Nerry

texts.en:
Nerry F., 52, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. Married to Primitivo Fontanillia, a construction cutter, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing their own computer shop, while selling ready-to-wear garments and bed sheets on the side.

Nerry has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends the weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow seven times in CCT’s Cooperative.

Nerry is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy things that her businesses need. Her three businesses let her earn a net profit of PHP 4,700 per month.

Now, with your help, Nerry would like to obtain a PHP 16,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding businesses by buying computer-related equipment plus clothes for her ready-to-wear business.

Nerry dreams that her businesses will grow and that someday she can have a shop in a mall to attract more customers and generate more income.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy computer equipment plus clothes for her ready-to-wear business

loans.name: Pelagie

texts.en:
Pelagie is 33 years old and is married with three children with ages 3, 6 and 9 years. She and her family live in Rulindo, in the Northern Province of Rwanda, approximately two hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Pelagie operates a business selling drinks made from sorghum. This is her tenth successful year in this business which she operates from early in the morning until 2 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Pelagie is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of purchasing more sorghum to make into drinks for sale. With this loan, she hopefully will be able to satisfy the demand of her customers as well as earn more profits than previously.

If Pelagie’s plan is successful, with the earned profits she will be able to reinvest in her business so that her business can keep growing.

loans.use: To buy more sorghum to make into drinks to sell

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria T., 27, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Married to Mr. T., a family driver, they are blessed with one child. She helps her husband earn income so their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for nine months.

Gloria has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for less than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow three times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy additional stock for her store.  She earns about PHP 4,400 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan which will be used to buy stock of instant noodles, snacks, and beverages for her store.  She prays that her life will continue to be peaceful and that God will be the center of their lives forever. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To stock her store with instant noodles, snacks, and beverages.

loans.name: Mr. Ngi

texts.en: Mr. Ngi T. lives in Srae Ampil village in Kandal province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land where he grows rice for a living. Unfortunately his field has developed infertile soil. In order to solve this problem, he requests a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides to support his rice farming. His wife, Mrs. Van Ran, is a housewife.  Mr. Ngi T. is 53 years old and the father of seven children, two of whom are laborers while another is a farmer and the others attend the local school. His wife is pictured on the right of the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides for rice farming.

loans.name: Karukara Group C, Kihihi

texts.en: Group leader Fred B. is 53 years old and married with 13 children out of which 11 are still in school at either the university, secondary, and primary school.  He also takes care of one sibling. Fred has been selling produce in Rukarara since 1999 and he is able to earn 350,000 UGX in monthly profits that help him take care of his family. Fred is such a hard working man and he is determined to ensure that he educates all his children well. He hopes also for the to have good health conditions. He needs a loan to help with buying more produce for resale so that his business can improve.

loans.use: To buy more produce for resale.

loans.name: Dilshod

texts.ru: Курбоназаров Дилшод проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 36 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Растениеводством занимается более 10 лет. Работает на арендованном учаске земли. Курбоназаров Дилшод обрабатывает почву для посева. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Dilshod K. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 36 years old, married and has 6 children. He has been involved in agriculture for over 10 years. He works on a leased piece of land. Dilshod treats the ground to prepare it for the planting. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard is 52 years old and is married with six children aged between 4 and 20 years. Bernard and his family live in Burera, in the Northern Province of Rwanda. There, Bernard operates his business of selling leather. This is his twentieth successful year in this business and the hours of his business are from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Bernard is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding his business through purchasing more leather, which hopefully will increase his profits. If this plan is successful, Bernard will continue to pay school fees as well as take care of his family. He will also save some profits, which in turn will allow him to make his business more stable.

loans.use: To buy more animal skins to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia F., 49, is making sure her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Fernando F., a civil engineer, and they are blessed with two children. She makes sure she helps her husband earn enough money so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for five years. She also sells vegetables on the side.

Lydia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow six times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy added stocks for her store. Her businesses let her earn an extra profit of 6,800 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 14,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying assorted snacks, beverages, and toiletries as added stocks for her store.

She dreams that her business will expand and that her family will have a better life in the near future. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying assorted snacks beverages and toiletries as added stocks for her store

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia T., 61, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Renato T., a carpenter, and ensures that she helps her husband earn an adequate income so their family can have a better life in the future.  She has been selling fish for 18 years. She also manages a junkshop.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding businesses by buying more fish products and added funds for her junkshop.

She dreams that she could see the lives of her children be far better than what they have experienced as they help each other in times of need. 

Julia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than four years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow 10 times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy stocks of fish to her store. Her businesses help her earn a combined profit of PHP 9,900 per month.  

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: fish products and added fund for her junkshop.

loans.name: Korotemogossigui Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Korotemogossigui sont  toutes mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygames traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans, 2 enfants et habitent toutes le chef lieu de commune rurale Cinzana Gare (4ème Région administrative de Ségou). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et d’appartenance à une même association  des femmes de Cinzana Gare. 
Ce groupe fait le commerce d’articles divers, céréales, condiments alimentaires etc.
C’est dans le souci d’améliorer et d’augmenter le volume de leurs activités commerciales, qu’elles décidèrent d’adhérer au programme  crédit  de Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt, elles sont à leur 2ème prêt  solidaire, qui sera utilisé pour acheter, un sac de riz, 2 sacs de choux pommés, 20kg d’ail, 2 sacs d’oignon (échalotes), un carton de thé, 10 paquets de bonbon, 15 paquets de chocolat et 25 kg de sucre. 
Elles s’approvisionnent sur place en  marchandises à la foire hebdomadaire de Cinzana Gare. Les produits sont revendus au comptant ou à crédit sur place au marché de Cinzana Gare et à domicile à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes et d’enfants. 
Elles espèrent  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 13.250 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour les soins de santé des enfants et réinvestir dans leurs activités génératrices de revenus. 
Elles ont pour ambition d’acheter des matériels agricoles.
texts.en:
The members of the Korotemogossigui group are all married women, the majority of them living in large traditional polygamous households. They average 30 years of age with two children each, and they all live in the county town of the rural community of Cinzana Gare (in the 4th administrative region of Ségou). They got to know each other through neighbors, relatives and through their belonging to the women's association in Cinzana Gare. This group trades various products, cereals, food condiments etc.. With a view to improving and increasing the volume of their business, they decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's (a micro-finance company) loan programme. Having repaid their first loan without incident, they are on their second group loan, which will be used to buy: a bag of rice, two bags of cabbages, 20kg of garlic, two bags of onions (shallots), a box of tea, ten packets of sweets, 15 packets of chocolate and 25 kg of sugar. They buy their stock locally at the weekly fair in Cinzana Gare. The products are sold on for cash or credit on the spot in the same market and also at home to a customer base made up of men, women and children. They hope to make an average monthly profit of 13,250 FCFA, which will be used for the children's healthcare and to reinvest in their revenue generating activities. Their ambition is to buy agricultural equipment.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various products

loans.name: Precila's Group

texts.en:
Precila B. is from the village of Awallan, Baggao, Cagayan. She is 55 years old. Precila is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Precila is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Precila owns & operates a business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and for sale. Precila has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Precila joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Precila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Precila is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros T., 42, is married to Gabriel T. who drives a jeepney, a small bus used for local transportation. They are blessed with four children. She has been selling beauty products and adding to the family’s income for the past three years so that the family can have a better life.

Milagros has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than four years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment record, she was able to take out eight previous loans from CCT’s Cooperative to buy assorted beauty products. Her business brings her a profit of 1,500 PHP per month while her husband earns 5,000 PHP from driving the jeepney.

Now she is requesting a 12,000 PHP loan as a source for added capital for her expanding business. With it she would buy a spare wheel and crude oil for their jeep plus additional soap products for her beauty product business. She dreams that they will be able to save enough money so that their children can finish their studies and enter Bible School someday.

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missionary work in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

Locally, all CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy a spare wheel and crude oil for their jeep, plus additional soap products for her beauty product business.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 30 years old and is married with two children, 2 and 4 years old. She and her family live in Musanze, a region of Ruhengeli, in the Northern Province of Rwanda.  From here to Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda it takes two hours drive.

Esther operates a business selling a variety of foodstuffs in her shop.  Those foodstuffs are tomatoes, bananas, cooking oil, con flour, Irish potatoes, soda etc.  This is her second successful year in her business and the hours of her business are from 7 a.m until late in the evening everyday except Sunday.

Esther is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that she can expand her business through purchasing more goods which hopefully will increase the number of her customers as well as increasing her profits in the process. This in turn will allow her and her devoted husband to start creating some other sources of income as well as creating more jobs in the community.

loans.use: Additional foodstuffs including tomatoes, bananas, cooking oil, con flour, Irish potatoes, soda etc...

loans.name: Saniya Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Saniya sont toutes mariées dans des grandes familles polygames traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 28 ans, 2 enfants et habitent le chef lieu de commune rurale Cinzana Gare (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et font essentiellement le commerce d’articles divers, les friandises etc.
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’intégrer  le  programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 2ème  prêt de groupe. Le premier fut correctement remboursé.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 4 sacs de farine de blé, 5 sacs de savon local (kabakuruni), 10 cartouches de thé, 20 paquets de bonbons, 40 paquets de chocolats, 1sac de sucre et 4cartouches d’allumette. 
Elles s’approvisionnent en  marchandises à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou. La farine de blé est frite avant la vente. Les autres produits sont revendus sur place au marché de Cinzana Gare et à domicile généralement au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes et d’enfants. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 14.300FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt  et acheter de la nourriture pour la famille.
Leur ambition est de diversifier les activités en embrassant l’élevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The five members of the Saniya group are all married in large traditional polygamous families. On average, they are 28-years-old with two children, and live in the seat of the rural area of Cinzana Gare (4th administrative region of Mali). They became acquainted as neighbours or through family links, and are essentially retailers of various items, sweets, etc. Wanting to better satisfy their customers, they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program where they are requesting their second group loan. The first one was fully reimbursed. The loan will be used to purchase: • 4 bags of wheat flour • 4 bags of local soap (kabakuruni) • 10 cartons of tea • 20 packages of sweets • 40 packages of chocolate • 1 bag of sugar • 4 cartons of matches They get their supplies from the weekly fair in Ségou. The wheat flour is fried before it is sold. The other products are resold locally at the Cinzana Gare market, or from their home, and is paid mainly in cash from a customer base of men, women, and children. They hope to reach an average monthly income of 14,300 FCFA per person, which will be used to reimburse the loan and buy food for their family. Their ambition is to diversify their activities by raising small farm animals.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Karukara Group D, Kihihi

texts.en:
Jolly K. is 49 years old and married with four children; she also takes care of two orphans. She is a friendly lady with a retail shop in the Kabingo trading center that she has been running for eight years. From her transactions Jolly is able to make 300,000 UGX in profits every month, and these help to recapitalize her business and take care of her family.

Jolly needs a loan to help her with restocking her shop with more goods like sugar, cooking oil, salt, bread and so on. She dreams of expanding her store as well as educating all of her children to be self-sustaining in the future.

loans.use: To restock her retail shop with more goods.

loans.name: Shahnoza

texts.ru: Нурова Шахноза проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 22 года. Не замужем. Животноводством занимается 2 года. Нурова Шахноза откармливает и продает скот. Кредит берет для закупа скота.
texts.en:
Shahnoza N. lives in the Shahrituz district. She is 22 years and single. She has been involved in animal husbandry for 2 years. Shahnoza raises and sells livestock. She is requesting this loan for the purchase of livestock.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Concepcion's Group

texts.en:
Concepcion C. is 44 years old with four school-aged children who lives in the village of Malalinta, San Manuel, Isabela. She is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Concepcion owns and operates her own general store from which she sells a variety of different products to the local community. Concepcion has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Concepcion joined ASKI to gain access to their financial services. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI which she used to buy additional products to sell, this will be the fourth loan taken out by Concepcion from ASKI. Concepcion is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP that will be used to purchase more new items to expand her product offerings. She plans to use all of her profits to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offerings

loans.name: Hawrank Zeeb Group

texts.en:
This is Hawrank Zeeb group. There are five members in this group. All members would like to receive money for their businesses. The group leader, Esmatullah is a married man with his six children, he wants to take a loan for his business of a battery-charging shop. He needs this money because he wants to buy essential supplies for his business. 

Yasamen wants to take a loan for her business of tailoring. She needs to purchase a machine and a desk for her business. And Hawrank Zeeb wants to take a loan for his business of a general store where he sells different kinds of things and supports all his family members. He would like to expand his business and buy some more materials for his shop to attract more clients. Nazefa wants to take a loan for her business of quilt-sewing. She wants to make her business larger. Noezeya wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of selling vegetables. He needs money because he wants to buy a new shop for his business.

They requested a group loan of 45,000 Afghani.

They all would like to state that Kiva is an effective process which can support all entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To buy necessary materials for their business

loans.name: Marites' Group

texts.en:
Marites T. is from the village of San Bonifacio, Burgos, Isabela. She is 30 years old. Marites is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Marites is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns and operates a general store. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Marites has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marites is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her range of products offered. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marites from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by the business to improve and expand the business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her range of products.

loans.name: Kahramon

texts.ru: Шомуродов Кахрамон проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 31 год. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Шомуродов Кахрамон занимается растениеводством более 5 лет. Он обрабатывает почву и сажает растение. Целью кредита является закуп семян.
texts.en:
Kahramon S. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 31 years old, married and has 3 children. Kahramon has been involved in agriculture for over 5 years. He treats the soil and plants plants. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Zawadi

texts.en:
Zawadi is 27 years old and is married with two children aged 2 months and 3 years. She and her family live in Musanze, a region of Ruhengeri, in the Northern Province of Rwanda, that is almost a two-hour drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Zawadi has been in the business of selling a variety of goods in her shop since 2008. Those goods include corn flour, cooking oil, rice, soap, etc. The hours of selling in her shop are from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day.

Zawadi is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of purchasing some additional goods for sale in her shop. Those goods are sugar, beans, rice, Irish potatoes, etc. With these additional goods, Zawadi is expecting to earn more profits that will help her to take good care of her family as well as enabling her to save a portion of them for the future.

Zawadi is thankful to any Kiva lender who is ready to contribute to the success of her business.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for her store

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan B. is from the town of Taggappan Echague. She is 34 years old. Joan is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Joan owns and operates a gown for rent business. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing rentals for gowns and barongs in the local community. Aside from that, she is also managing a catering business. Joan has been engaged in her businesses for over 14 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Joan joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joan is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Joan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Ismoil

texts.en:
Ismoil is a very hard-working and responsible entrepreneur. He and his family live in Penjikent, Tajikistan. He is married with two children. Ismoil works in the central city market selling clothing: jeans, jackets, shirts and other items. His business is characterized by stability and consistent growth. He has been working in the market for five years. Once a month he travels to the neighboring city for purchasing new goods. Ismoil likes to work for himself. His business has been the main source of income for his whole family. Today Ismoil would like to ask for a loan of $2000 USD to purchase winter clothing from wholesalers and increase the assorted merchandise in his store. We believe Ismoil’s drive for success will help this young entrepreneur succeed and thrive in business. You can be an important part of the growth of Ismoil’s business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new clothing for resale.

loans.name: Jovid

texts.en:
N. Jovid is 25 years old. He sells confectionery like candy, cookies and pastries wholesale as well as retail. He has been in this business for two years. The generated income allows him to support his family, since he is the breadwinner of the family. Today Jovid is requesting $2500 USD. He is going to spend the loan on purchasing more confectionery to enlarge his range of goods. Jovid thanks everybody for their support and promises to repay the loan in time.

loans.use: Purchasing confectionery to enlarge the range of goods offered.

loans.name: Karina

texts.en:
Karina V. is from the village of Centro 2, Mallig, Isabela. She is 32 years old. Karina is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Karina owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Karina has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Karina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Karina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her range of products. Karina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to sell. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Karina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Odil

texts.en:
Odil O. is 27 years old. He is married and runs his own business. He is an expert in computer services, and provides services such as: internet, printing, scanning, lamination, etc. He has been in this business for five years already. At the same time, for additional income, Odil has been running a business raising and selling cattle with the help of his father. Odil tries to use modern up-to-date technologies in his work to satisfy the demands and requirements of the customers. For instance, now he is planning to purchase a new modern computer in order to improve the quality of his work and to expand the business. For this purpose Odil is requesting US$3000. With part of the loan he will also purchase young cattle. Odil thanks all lenders for their support and promises not to let down his lenders and to pay the loan in time.

loans.use: Purchasing a new modern computer and young cattle.

loans.name: Richard Kandie

texts.en:
Richard Kandie is a 27-year-old man married to Evanshia Sambu who is also 27 years old. Richard and Evanshia have been blessed with two children: Edmond Kandie and Mercy Chelimo who are 5½ and 4 years old, respectively.

Richard’s primary business is a hotel (this term is used locally to mean a food service establishment), which is two years old and yields a profit of Kshs 26,000 per month. He gets additional income from farming which comes to about Kshs 3,000 per month. Richard’s customers are mainly residents of Kabarnet Town and those visiting the town.

Mr. Kandie plans to use the Kshs 20,000 from KADET limited to purchase stock for the hotel. This loan marks his first loan from KADET. Whatever profit he earns he plans to use to boost his business by expanding his hotel to be able to accommodate about 100 customers per sitting. He also plans to offers accommodation or rather lodging services to his customers, which he doesn’t do at the moment.

Richard dreams of expanding his hotel business to a five star hotel. He also hopes to give his children the best education he can afford.

Richard describes himself as hard-working and determined to achieve his goals.

loans.use: To purchase stock for the hotel.

loans.name: Uktam

texts.en:
Uktam is 47 years old and lives with his wife and four children. He is a humble farmer dedicated to producing vegetables. Every year he makes a good profit from his land and with the money he saved he has purchased a car to transport his crops. Currently Uktam needs to invest large amounts of money, because he knows that on a larger harvest, he will have better results, and his vegetables have to be of better quality in order to get more income from the sales. Uktam dedicates his efforts to the well-being of his family, particularly his children.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Rahimdjon

texts.en:
Rahimdjon is the humble father of two children who depend on him economically and who are his driving force in life. Rahimdjon leases farmland for a season at a time, since he does not own land. He cultivates his crops and then sells them, but his profits are decreased by the land payments. Therefore, Rahimdjon wishes to quickly acquire his own land, where he can sow his crops calmly and increase the amount of revenue that he brings home. To make that a reality, he needs to increase his production and especially the quality of his products to make them more profitable in the marketplace. This will bring better profits and he will then be able to acquire a plot of land. The amount required by Rahimdjon at the moment is $1200 USD for the purchase of fuels and lubricants, seeds and mineral fertilizer. We hope that you will be of great help to this hard-working father.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing fuels and lubricants, seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael O. lives in the town of Kakamega. He is married to Caroline O. and they have three children. Michael’s wife is a nursery school teacher.

Michael is in the construction industry where he uses a poker machine to put concrete on floors of houses that have been built.

He hopes to get a lender through Kadet Limited to enable him buy another poker concrete vibrator machine to enable him do his business well since the one he has is old and outdated. 

Michael’s dream is to buy a concrete mixer, a complete poker vibrator and a crane. He also hopes to be able to send his children to a higher institution of education.

loans.use: To buy another concrete vibrator machine.

loans.name: Andre

texts.en:
Andre is 27 years old and is married with one child a year-and-a-half old. Andre and his family live in Rulindo, in the Northern Province of Rwanda. It is approximately two hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Andre has been running his business of selling foodstuffs since 2008 and the hours of her business are from early in the morning until evening hours everyday.

Andre, after realizing that the number of his customers keeps growing and that he is not able to satisfy their demand with his existing capital, decided he needs to request a Kiva loan, which will help him to cover all the needs of his customers.

Through using this loan, Andre hopefully will earn more profits which, in turn will be used to reinvest in his business as well as saving for the future of his business so that one day he will find himself financially stable.

loans.use: To buy additional foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Bintou

texts.fr:
Description 	Madame  Bintou Traoré  est âgée de 49 ans, mariée  et mère  de 5 enfants.  Elle  vit chez son mari dans une grande famille traditionnelle au 2ème quartier de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elle a abandonné l’école en classe de 3 ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour  mener plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus telles la coiffure, la teinture etc. Finalement elle opte pour les activités de fabrication traditionnelle de savon. Ce métier, elle l’a appris auprès d’une de ses connaissances. Après des semaines d’apprentissage, elle finit par maîtriser la technique de fabrication et ainsi alla s’installer à son propre compte. Elle mène cette activité depuis 4 ans et jouit d’une grande réputation car elle produit des savons traditionnels de bonnes qualités.
Pour faire du savon traditionnel, elle brûle 50litres d’huiles de karités dans une marmité ou dans une barrique ensuite elle met 5 bidons de 20litres d’eaux, 5 kg de farines  et 4kgs de soudes caustiques dans cette marmite. Puis elle procède au remuage à l’aide d’une grande louche jusqu’avoir la pâte servant de savon.   
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 48 mois. Après 4 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 30 barriques de soude caustique. Elle s’approvisionne sur place. Madame  Bintou Traoré  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle constituée de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra d’aider son mari et de participer aux événements sociaux (baptême, mariage etc.…).
texts.en:
Mrs. Bintou Traoré is 49-years-old, married and mother of five children. She lives with her husband in a large traditional family in the second area of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She stopped going to school in the third primary grade (Mali education system) to begin several revenue-generating activities such as hairdressing, dying clothes, etc. She finally opted for traditional soap-making. She learned this trade from one of her acquaintances. After weeks of apprenticeship, she finally mastered the production technique and started her own business. She has been pursuing this activity for the past four years and has acquired a high reputation due to the quality of her traditional soaps. To make traditional soap she heats 50 litres of Shea oil in a large pot or in a barrel. She then adds five 20-litre containers of water, five kilos of flour and four kilos of caustic soda. She then stirs with a large ladle until she obtains a paste-like consistency from which she will make the soap. To increase the size of her business and to generate more revenue, she approached Soro Yiriwaso four years ago. Folllowing four group and two individual loans, all of which were fully reimbursed, she is now requesting a third individual loan. She will use this loan to purchase 30 barrels of caustic soda. She gets her supplies locally. Mrs. Binton Traoré sells cash and on credit to a customer base of women. With this loan, she hopes to reach a monthly revenue of 100,000 FCFA. This will enable her to assist her husband and participate in the funding of social events (baptisms, weddings, etc.).

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy caustic soda

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 60 years old and is married with two children. She and her family live in Musanze, in the Northern Province of Rwanda.

In her village, Christine owns a shop selling a variety of goods such as cosmetics products. This is her second successful year in this business and the hours of her business are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Christine is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase her working capital. This will allow her to purchase some additional goods to sell including some foodstuffs like sugar, rice, beans and Irish potatoes as well as more cosmetics products and underwear. Those goods seem to be highly in demand by her customers.

With these additional goods for sale, Christine will earn more profits. With these profits, she will be able to build a secure future for her business as well as for her family.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for sale such as foodstuffs, cosmetics goods and underwear

loans.name: María

texts.es:
La señora Maria N.  vive en casa en anticretico en la zona  de Bajo San Antonio, ladera este de la ciudad de La Paz, con su hijo.
La señora Maria trabaja como empleada en la administración pública, ingresos con los que se mantiene.
El crédito solicitado es para aumentar el contrato de su anticretico, exigido por la dueña de casa y no tener que trasladarse a otra vivienda.
Esta es la primera vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado la califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Mrs. María N. lives with her child in a house held under rental obligation in the Bajo San Anotonio zone, on the east side of the city of La Paz. María works as an employee in public administration for the income that maintains her family. The loan she requests in to increase her payments on the rental contract, as demanded by the owner of the house, to avoid having to move to another dwelling. This is the first time she has solicited a loan and the socioeconomic analysis that was performed judges her qualified. She may obtain a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO INCREASE RENTAL PAYMENTS ON THE HOUSE SHE LIVES IN

loans.name: Mohamad Nizar

texts.en: Mohamad Nizar is a 20-year-old single man who lives with his parents and two unemployed brothers. In 2007, he decided to help his father support the family by working as an electrician. Today, Mohamad Nizar is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy additionA. electric tools and equipment in order to expand his business and increase productivity.

loans.use: buy additional electric tools and equipment

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is 40 years old and married with one seven-year-old child in school. She rents a one-roomed house which she shares with three other people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets two meals a day. Evelyn is a tailor in Katanga and also sells airtime. She incurs transportation costs to and from Owino market — one of  the busiest markets in Uganda — where she buys the materials she needs to make her clothes. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. During her seven-day work week she sees an average of 10 customers a day, both retail and wholesale. Her biggest monthly expenses are feeding the family and school fees for her child. Her major business challenge is the rainy season since she works in a muddy place where her customers have trouble getting to her. Evelyn has been in this business for four years and with MCDT for six years, servicing her seventh loan, working with the same group. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and worked with poor women. She wants this loan to buy more clothing materials and airtime. She hopes to see her business grow and also to start a tailoring school .

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials

loans.name: Fadel

texts.en: Fadel is married with three school-age children. He supports his family by providing electricity to his village with his electric motor, having seen a need for such a service in 2005. Today, Fadel is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy electric cables and perform maintenance on the motor in order to expand his business to cover a wider region.

loans.use: buy electric cables and perform maintenance for the motor

loans.name: Khaled
